INTERSECTION OF THE ALLEY AND THE STREET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the fountain at El Pueblo. A jet of waiter rises into air at regular intervals, tossing an empty ball in rhythm Below the ball, the water cascades into the second tier o the fountain. SUPERIMPOSED over this fountain are the mai and credit titles. Throughout the running of the titles w hear castanet music growing louder and louder. When the l credit title FADE OFF we begin to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corridor, backstage at El Pueblo. An empty corridor stretches away before us. The CAMERA TRUCKS ALONG this corridor. The sound of the castanets is so loud and ringi now that it has a furious and stormlike quality. The came seems to search for the source of this sound. It approach two open doorways at the end of the corridor. Through the doorway on the right we see a dancer in Spani costume. She pirouettes in a final whirl of the dance as CAMERA MOVES IN TO a CLOSE SHOT of her beautiful back and two castanets she holds up over her gleaming naked should Over the diminishing trill of the castanets, as the dance finishes her dance we hear a dull and angry pounding. The castanets click to an end. The CAMERA MOVES LEFT to take in the adjoining door to sh us the source of this sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki Walker as she finishes pounding on the wall for sile in the adjoining dressing room and turns back into her ow room. She is young, blonde and represents that peculiar phenomenon of our time, the chorus girl and entertainer w is more lady-like than the majority of Junior Leaguers. R shows, one night stands and even a short turn in burlesqu have left no battle scars. She may know many a hard word, she never uses it. MED. SHOT - Kiki's room. Kiki slams shut the door of her dressing room. Her dressing room is a small bare cubicle a sink, easy chair, dressing table and a long mirror on t closet door. On the dressing table, among a clutter of ja and ointments, is a small musical trinket box. The closet door is partially ajar. In the room with Kiki is Eloise, the cigarette girl at th Pueblo, a brightly blondined young lady. Her nether limbs well display in black stockings. A cigarette tray is slun over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she walks across the room) It may sound like music to her -- I can do better with my teeth in a cold Shower. (mockingly) Click В— click В— click.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) She's a local. When the dudes come out to New Mexico, they went to wallow in Latin glamour. This is a bad town for blondes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. So I've noticed. Jerry's noticed -В— He'll come up with something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think be's pretty nice, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? He's a good press agent and a good friend. Besides, we've shared a lot of headaches В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky. I wish he'd front page for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. For three years I've sung in rats' nests, while Jerry pounded his feet off and his brains out -- trying to get me a real chance. We're due for a little luck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki walks across to the make-up table and sits down in f of it, lifting her hands to unwrap the towel which is wra around her head to protect it from make-up. Eloise starts toward the door, but pauses to admire herself in the mirr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean this personally, Miss Walker, but it's ironic В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pauses, striking a pose the better to look at her own sleek legs in the minor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean you being a star and me being just a cigarette girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning from (the mirror to look at Eloise) I know. I know. You've got the talent. I got the breaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns back to the mirror. NED. CLOSE REFLECTION SHOT of Eloise. We see Eloise admir herself in the long mirror and also the edge of the dress room door as it slowly begins to swing open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear it in night club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eloise can see what is opening the door. She lets loose w a shriek of mortal terror. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Kiki. She whirls quickly and rises, he mouth open in a soundless ejaculation of fright. REVERSE SHOT - the door. Through the doorway comes the bl spade-shaped head of a panther, ears wickedly flat, muzzl the floor. He starts into the room with a terrifying zigz undulation. Eloise yips feebly. Kiki screams. As the panther advances into the room, one can see that i held on a taut leash. Holding the leash is Jerry Manning, with a wide, pleasant smile of reassurance on his lips. CLOSE SHOT Kiki on top of the dressing table. She stands there holding her dressing gown back across her knees in terror. The little jewel box has fallen to the floor, and insipid tinkling tune fills the room as it rolls across t floor toward the panther. MED. SHOT - Kiki, Eloise, Jerry and the panther. Kiki sta on top of the dressing table; Eloise has retreated behind chair, and Jerry stands between them, grinning, holding t leash of the panther, which is nosing forward to examine music box

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hitting high C) Get it out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki -- he won't hurt you. There's nothing to be afraid of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes no difference. Get him out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Kicks, you'll never guess what I've cooked up this tine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's easy. Me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought -- is Kiki just going to walk on that floor tonight В—В—walk out cold before a bunch of gawks who think a Spanish twirler is the greatest thing in life. No. Not my favorite client. She's going to make an entrance this town will never forget!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the leopard) On his back, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kidding her) No. I thought that might be just a little corny. I want you to lead him in on a leash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too good to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Kicks, have I ever done anything to hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No В—- not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quite sincerely and with evident affection) And I never will- you know what's between us В— we're a thing  But this is serious competition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hitting high C) Get it out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki - he won't hurt you. There's nothing to be afraid of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes no difference.  Get him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Kicks, you'll never guess what I've cooked up this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's easy. Me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought -В— is Kiki just going to walk on that floor tonight walk out cold before a bunch of gawks who think a Spanish twirler is the greatest thing in life. No. Not my favorite client. She's going to make an entrance  this town will never forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the leopard) On his back, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kidding her) No. I thought that might be just a little corny.  I want you to lead him in on a leash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too good to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sentimentally) Look, Kicks, how long have we known each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) This is l939. Can't you subtract?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost three years, isn't it? And have I ever done anything to hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No В—В— not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quite sincerely and with evident affection) And I never will -- you know what's between us -В— we're a thing -- But this is serious -- big competition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating leopard) I thought you might strut this kitten in right in the middle of her act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki grins. Jerry reaches for Kiki's hand, and passes the of the leash over her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come down to earthВ— and see what a picture you'd make with this for a pet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeping a wary eye on the leopard, Kiki lets Jerry help h down. She stands as far away from the beast as the leash permit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warily, from behind the chair) And if you've got cold feet honey, Ill take over for you. That red dress of yours fits just perfect on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated, turning to her) I bet you try on my coffin some day -- I hope it "fits just perfect."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hastily to Kiki) You look swell in that threeВ—alarm number --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red dress? (thinks a moment) No. My black one. Then I'll be just like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CL0SE SHOT - the fountain. The CAMERA is FOCUSED on the extreme height of the jet of water. We watch the ball on of this jet as it rises and falls for a few beats. Over t shot we hear the music of a Mexican orchestra. The CAMERA MOVES DOWN and BACK to reveal the upper tier o the fountain with the water flowing over its edges.  The CAMERA MOVES BACK and we see the wide pool at the bas the fountain. In this pool we see Clo-Clo reflected, as s dances. The CAMERA PANS to take in the actual dancer and we see C Clo whirling and turning in a tight circle. She is illuminated by several baby spots concealed at the base of the fountain, and this light makes a nimbus of light around her. It is a sort of superaura which washes out th background haze, leaving the dancer clear-cut and sharp i the midst of this superaura. As Clo-Clo's dance widens in movement, taking her to the of the light nimbus, we can see her, the tables and the patrons of El Pueblo. The El Pueblo cafe is the smartest night club in this sma New Mexican resort town. The main dining room is in the patio. Here are tables mantled in snowy tablecloths, glittering candlelight and sparkling glassware. On the po is an open space for the performers and the orchestra on side  On the other side is a bar. Tonight, El Pueblo is crowded. Waiters, dressed in rather formal costumes with black trousers and short, white coat scurry between the tables. A good portion of -the patrons in evening clothes. CloВ—Clo dances. The rhythmic rattle of her castanets bea above the orchestra. Clo-Clo is New Mexican. Like the broncos of her native st she is all fine, proud, pure Spanish blood. It has suffer change in the high clear air of New Mexico. In her dance, too, we see the more primeval strain of the Indian twiste among the finer threads of Spanish rhythm. She dances. In the pool we see the heavy flutter and turn her skirt. Her neck, her bosom, her arms, bend and sway a turn and pulse with the bloodbeat of the castanets. She i just entering a graceful turn of the dance, the castanets beginning a glissade, when suddenly she stops dead, the c of the castanets cutting off abruptly. REVERSE SHOT - the doorway leading into the El Pueblo. Fr in this doorway is Kiki, slim and tall in a black gown wi black gloves, and in her outstretched hand is a black lea which links her to the leopard. Behind her the doorway is with light so that we see her dramatic outline, a silhoue against luminosity. MED. LONG SHOT - the cafe. A buzz of amazement sounds fro the crowd. There is a flutter of astonishment and timidit CLOSEUP of CloВ—Clo. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Kiki. Behind her in the doorway Jerry Manning's face appears. It is obvious that Kiki, despite dramatic pose, is surreptitiously nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) Don't stand here, Kiki. You're on stage. They're looking at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki moves majestically forward. MED. LONG SHOT В— a table near the dance space. Kiki, the leopard moving before her, threads her way between two tables, the patrons drawing away from her black escort as passes. A waiter, carefully holding the chair between him the leopard, makes a place for her at an empty table. CloВ—Clo, feet wide apart, arms and hands still half rais and holding the castanets, watches. The orchestra plays feebly on. Suddenly CloВ—Clo smiles. She lifts her hands a little hi takes a step forward and lets the castanets loose with a that sounds like machineВ—gun fire. The leopard startled, twists in a half turn of fright, strains suddenly at the leash and lunges forward. The leash pulls out of Kiki's frightened hand. REFLECTION SHOT in the pool. The still water reflects the quick bound and leap of the leopard in its panic flight f freedom. MED. CLOSE SHOT - Kiki. She stands leaning against the ta trembling in fright. Behind her CloВ—Clo can be seen can seen on the platform, smiling. Jerry comes into the scene puts his arm about Kiki's waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wildly, and in disgust) Now look what you've done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The familiar tone of anger reassures Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (briefly) You are all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - the leopard bounding through the gate. MED. SHOT at the gate. A waiter with a napkin over his ar and a water carafe in his hand, stands aghast, pressing h back to the wall in fear. The water carafe falls with a crash. The waiter holds up his hand, dazed. His hand is streaming with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOT of four policemen, their backs toward us, going thro the Alley of the Shadows. Two of them are beating on pots pans to make a noise. Two others are flashing their flashlights from one side to the other. We TRUCK WITH them down the alley. They bring us to the o end of the passage, athwart which a fire truck is parked. Near this fire truck stands the Chief of Police, Robles, dignified, wellВ—spoken, Mexican police officer, serious conscientious, very much on duty at all times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No leopard, Chief -- no cat, no kittens, nothing. We're going to tackle the houses

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robles nods. He makes a gesture to one of the men on the truck and two long lances of light pierce the darkness of alley. LONG SHOT - Pasaje De Las Sombras. The shafts of light fr the searchlights cross and re-cross, moving, as they expl the dark jags and corners of the alley. It is one of the oldest streets in town, so narrow that even at noonday, t sun has difficulty lightening its dark shadows. The adobe houses, standing wall to wall, were never built on any straight geometric line; the street makes a dog-leg, meandering, as if loathe to reach its own blind end. MED. LONG SHOT В— the mouth of the alley at the other sid the fire truck. This is a-scene of curiosity and confusio police cordon has been erected, and several uniformed Mex policemen are busy shooing away the spectators, foiling t attempts of small boys to get under the ropes, and genera trying to reduce chaos to an ordered hunt for the leopard At the mouth of the alley, next to the fire truck is park curious conveyance, a half-ton truck with a gaudy sign wh reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaning against a fender of this vehicle is Jerry Manning hot, disheveled and excited. He is talking with a short Indian, Charlie HowВ—Come, dressed in Levis, a velvet Zun jacket, and with a battered felt hat on his coarse black hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember what you said: Ten bucks for the loan of my cat В—-two hundred and twenty-five if anything happened to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry tries to control his exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with strained patience) But nothing has happened to it. It got into this alley, and there's no way out of it. They'll find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't get the idea, Mister. These cops banging those pans, flashing those lights -В— they're going to scare that poor cat of mine, Cats are funny. They don't want to hurt you -- but if you scare them -В— they go crazy. These cops don't know what they're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little Mexican boy who has seen listening to the conversation between Jerry and Charlie, is suddenly attra by something off in the darkness. Grinning, he turns on t hand flashlight he is holding and points it off into the darkness of the alley. MED. CLOSE SHOT - Clo-Clo's legs. The flashlight picks up pair of shapely legs and holds on them as they move forwa The legs stop their walking motion and suddenly begin to stamp with the heel taps that are part of her dance. The light snaps off. MED. SHOT - Jerry and Charlie. CloВ—Clo comes in from the left. She grins at the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jerry) Maybe, Mr. Manning would like to help me? I do not need a leopard. I have talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry is furious and about to make some retort. CloВ—Clo laughs and takes her hands from her pockets. She is holdi her castanets, and a ribald rattle drowns anything Jerry might want to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving off) Goodnight, Mr. Publicity Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry glares after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a small flower shop. One or two vases hold wilted flowers which have been left in the display window. Behin them is a mirror. In this mirror we can see the mouth of alley and Clo-Clo as she walks away from the men and come toward the flower shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CloВ—Clo passes the flower shop and continues on. The CAMERA TRUCKS WITH her. She passes several dark doorw and comes abreast of a dimly lit shop. Behind the grimy window of this store is a large handВ—lettered sign:

dialogues.speaker: HAND OR CARD
dialogues.text: From the dark doorway of this store, a voice calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you hurrying, Clo-Clo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a derisive twitter of her castanets) Oh, it's you. Faker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly a white, thin hand and arm appears from the shad of the doorway. The hand holds a deck of cards, extending them toward Clo-Clo temptingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a card, Clo-Clo. See what the night holds for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo hesitates. Looks at the deck of cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your cards are a joke. I wouldn't give you a centavo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to move away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One card CloВ—Clo -- for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo stops. Pretending indifference, she casually reac out and takes a card. INSERT        ACE OF SPADES in Clo-Clo's hand. MED. CLOSE SHOT of CloВ—Clo as she stares at the card. Sh laughs and flips the card back into the darkness of the doorway, letting the castanets in her other hand speak of disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts off along the street. CAMERA TRUCKS WITH her. She passes an open doorway. In th shadow lounges a tall thin man, his figure merging with t darkness. He is smoking. We can see the glow of his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in passing) Hello, Shorty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man disregards a verbal reply, but blows a smoke ring toward her. She pokes' her index finger through the ring playfully and goes on. The CAMERA MOVES WITH her. In the area way of the next building are two lovers, pressed close to each other and close to the wall..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oo! Oo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protestingly) Clo-Clo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo goes on. From a window a young girl is peeping, looking up and down the street with large frightened eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Hello, Chiquita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling back, a little hesitantly) Hello, Clo-Clo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo goes on, but our CAMERA REMAINS. This is Teresa Delgado, a wisp of a young girl, whose childish, smooth f might go unnoticed if it were not for her enormous and wistful dark eyes. She has on a skimpy cotton dress drawn at the waist with a five-and-ten cent store belt. Having looked again up and down the street she pulls down the sa and turns back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Delgado house is typical of the poorer Mexican homes New Mexico. This main room, which is small, serves as liv room, bedroom and kitchen. An Indian blanket covers the doorway into the only other room. The adobe walls are plastered with pictures of religious subjects. The wooden floor is bare. There is a charcoal-burning bra in one corner. Pots and pans on the hearth of the firepla show that it is a supplementary stove, The rest of the furniture consists of an iron bedstead, a large and hideo oak table and an open-faced china cabinet which contains Delgado treasures. Pedro, Teresa's nine-year-old brother is seated at the oa table, eating from a bowl of frijoles. He is, and looks l an imp. Teresa is backing away from her mother, who turns away from the window to face her angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evidently resuming a discussion) But, Mamacita -- why can't Pedro go this time? I'm so tired...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (complacently) I'm too young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your father comes home and there are no tortillas, he will shout В—В— and tomorrow it will be all over town: the family of Juan Delgado is too poor to buy corn meal! Do you wish we should be so disgraced?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teresa shakes her head, but makes no move to go. Exaspera Sra. Delgado reaches for the nearest weapon -- the broom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sra. Delgado brandishes the broom toward Teresa, who back again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what she's afraid of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pedro lifts his hand. It casts a sharp shadow on the wall behind him. Watching the shadow, he manipulates his finge so as to create the shadow of a leopard's head in miniatu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what, por todos los santos, is "this"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teresa braves the threatening broom and moves a step towa her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eager to be believed) The leopard, Mamacita. They say a lady at the El Pueblo had it on a string and it ran away. It hasn't been found yet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A leopard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gleefully) They're big -- and they jump on you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pedro jumps the shadow on the wall, to simulate the leap leopard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furiously) Did you ever meet one of those things yet when you went to the store for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teresa swallows, shakes her head mutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bellowing) Then you won't meet one this time either! Now get out! Do as I told you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sra. Delgado gives the broom such a backward swing of fin purpose that Teresa hurriedly opens the door behind her a slinks out backwards -- her big liquid dark eyes, still futilely pleading, the last to disappear. Sra. Delgado mo after her, pushing the door closed. She puts the broom in the corner and goes to where Pedro seated. Here she stands a moment, fondly watching him as masticates his beans. Behind her the door stealthily open Teresa tries to sneak back into the room. Mamacita sees t movement and makes a tempestuous rush toward her, but Ter sidles out of the door before she can be caught. Mamacita muttering, slams the door shut and with difficulty pushes heavy, rust-covered iron bolt into place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teresa stands outside the door. We hear the heavy bolt in driven home forcibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now В—В— you will not come in again, not until you bring the corn meal with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teresa steps down from the single doorstep outside her ho She crosses her arms and pulls her shoulders together in gesture of fear. She looks once, despairingly, at the clo door behind her В—В— and then reluctantly steps out into dirt road and starts walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a large corner window, with the word. "Provisiones" printed on it shows that this ordinary house is a grocery store. In the moonlight, one can see a few boxes of groce stacked on shelves inside. Teresa comes up to the window peers in. She knocks on the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senora Calderon It is Teresa, Senor. Teresa Delgado.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over Teresa's shoulder, we see the interior of the little store light up dimly as a curtain is pulled at the back o the room. Beyond the curtain is revealed another room, brightly lit by a bare electric globe hanging from the ceiling on a cord. Under the light, a man sits at a table heartily eating from a plate heaped with food. The curtai has been pulled back by Senora Calderon. We see her only silhouette and the details of her face and figure are indistinguishable. We do see, however, that her long blac hair is down her back and she is braiding it. She walks a little ways into the darkened store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking loudly to be heard through the window) The store is closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want a sack of corn meal for my father's supper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imploringly) It'll just take a second. ..Please В—В—or I must go clear across the Arroyo to the big grocery --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teresa taps against the window hopefully. But Sra. Calder turns back toward the doorway into the inner room, where solitary feaster hasn't even bothered to look up during t exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she goes) It means taking off the lock again, putting on the light, measuring the meal. It's too much trouble. Once I close, I close!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sm. Calderon steps into the inner room and draws the curt closed behind her, as she speaks the last words. Again th store is in darkness -- only a rim of light showing aroun the edges of the curtained doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly В— hopelessly) Senora...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no reply. Teresa turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Arroyo is a deep narrow cut in the mesa, boneВ—dry in season. Its floor of bleached sand and weeds stretches desolately wider a vast moonlit sky. Here and there, children's feet have scuffed steep little trails down the banks. Teresa appears at the top of one of these trails. She loo down into the Arroyo -- and then off to the right. A distance down the Arroyo is a bridge which carries a tr track across the dry river bed. To divert the rush of rai water in winter and spring, the bridge is underpropped by slanting stone piers. They stand out like ribs against th blackness of the underpass, which they divide into three tunnels. Teresa's face shows her dread of the Arroyo. She turns ba the way she came, takes a step away, hesitates and then returns to the edge of the bank. She starts down the little trail, her feet sliding in the loose sand and a shower of pebbles bouncing down ahead of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teresa stands at the bottom of the bank. She looks off to bridge again. Then she starts walking forward slowly, a v little figure in the large loneliness of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teresa comes up to the face of the underpass with its thr openings. She stares from one black tunnel mouth to anoth She glances behind her, then looks at the underpass again Teresa goes forward again, toward the middle tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roof of the underpass is only a little higher than Teresa's head and the passage is not more than ten feet w The opening is dimly lit by the moonlight, but beyond it dense blackness. Teresa enters slowly. She takes a few st toward the blackness В—- and stops. She listens. Teresa m forward again, walking as lightly as possible. The light rapidly, so that after Teresa has taken a half dozen step she is swallowed up in complete blackness. The CAMERA HOLDS for a moment on the dark underpass befor Teresa emerges from the blackness on the West side. A lig scratching sound is heard. Teresa's eyes widen in panic a she hears it and she hurries out of the tunnel, watching fearfully ever her left shoulder. She must cut across in front of this other tunnel in order to get to the south b She starts across, never taking her eyes off the black tu mouth. Suddenly she gives a convulsive start and a little escapes before she can control it. A shadowy shape, low t the ground, detaches itself from the dimness of the tunne opening and moves toward her. Almost at once, we see that is a large tumbleweed, blowing clown the Arroyo in the wi Teresa sighs soundlessly and goes on to the foot of the b She starts scrambling up another steep little path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a fairly goodВ—sized room, lined with shelves and counters. A tall, Indian-type Mexican with iron-grey hair puts a paper sack of cornmeal on the counter in front of Teresa. She starts toward the door, but noticing a bronze cage wi two toy birds in it, a mechanical device which has stood there for years, she goes toward it, puts down her sack o corn meal and goes up close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the toy birds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've seen them before. I couldn't chase you away from the counter when you were a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She winds up the bird cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd forgotten them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, goodhumoredly, skeptical) Every day you see them --and you have forgotten them? Oh, I remember my little Teresita -- I remember the little girl who was afraid of the dark. They shouldn't send you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The birds have begun to sing,a highly mechanical renderin a bird song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid. What could happen to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The birds sing and she pretends to listen. Manuel leans against the inner door of the grocery watching her, smili and amused. Finally his smiling irks her into action. She picks up her sack of corn meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she starts off) I'll pay you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never fear - - next time you come. The poor don't cheat one another. We're all poor together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bronze cage the two birds continue to sing their mechanical song. Their heads turn from side to side. We hear the door close behind Teresa. The birds are still singing as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a sound of slow, measured dripping. It comes fro water seeping out between two rocks and dropping onto ano rock below. These rocks are piled up at the juncture of t bridge and the left bank and the water is evidently leaki from some water main or sews go pipe running under the highway overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teresa is approaching the entrance of the middle tunnel, is evidently scared В—- her footsteps are lagging and she holds the sack of corn meal in both hands, as if feeling weight. She looks fearfully at the black tunnel before he and comes to a standstill, trying to peer into the blackn In the silence, the dripping of the water can be heard. Teresa looks up and to the left to locate the sound. She the shining dampness on the rocks. She turns back to the middle tunnel before her -- and, drawing a deep breath of resolution, starts to enter it. But she hesitates and the suddenly, veers over to the left. She peers into the open of that tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wall of the tunnel is also damp with the seepage from above. It reflects the outer moonlight in glistening stre so that the blackness here is not so complete as in the o tunnel..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teresa gets a fresh grip on the bag of corn meal by shift her hands under it -- and walks into the entrance of the north tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, the crunching sound of Teresa's footsteps are magnified in the enclosure of the tunnel walls. It is ver dim, but the luminosity of the damp wall casts a faint li on Teresa, reflecting in her wide, frightened eyes. She w slowly and lightly, her eyes going from side to side in t darkness, her neck and head held rigidly. Suddenly she st with a sharp intake of breath, Ahead of her and to her le are two tiny gleams of light. Teresa backs away from them she does so, they seem to fall and vanish. Slowly Teresa moves forward again, staring at the place w the lights had been. As she moves parallel to the spot, t appear again. A half-cry dies away in her throat --she se that the gleams are two drops of seepage, trickling down side of the tunnel wall. Teresa half closes her eyes and sways a little, faint with fear. Then she forces herself move forward again. She takes one -- two fearful steps -- then the underpass reverberates with a sudden tremendous shock of sound -В— more a giant vibration than actual noi It is a train passing overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Teresa stands transfixed, the terrific roar continues. Second after second, flashes of light as brilliant as lightning illuminate the interior of the tunnel В— the reflections thrown into the Arroyo by the train windows. then, as abruptly as it began, the noise ceases. It is cavernously dark in the tunnel again. In this thick stillness, Teresa walks forward once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the frame of the tunnel opening, Teresa stands for a moment. Behind her, there is a new sound -- a mere whispe sound carried forward on the light wind. A little shower rubble falls from the top of the concrete pier. Teresa tu to look behind her. Crouched on one of the piers of the trestle -В— and seen very dimly in the darkness -- is the leopard, looking dow into the Arroyo. An enormous big HEAD CLOSEUP of Teresa. An enormous big HEAD CLOSEUP of the leopard, its clear go eyes fixed and staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teresa's nails dig into the paper sack of corn meal and little trickles of the meal start spilling from the slits Her eyes widen and her face falls slack from the horrible shock of what she sees. She turns and runs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT EDGE OF ARROYO
dialogues.text: Teresa scrambles frantically up over the edge of the bank She stumbles ana falls and the sack of corn meal drops fr her hands and spills onto the ground. In a single move, Teresa is on her feet and running again. A shadow flashes over the spilled meal and we hear a heavy, ripping snarl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is quiet and peaceful in the Delgado home. Senora Delg is puttering about the brasero. Pedro, on all fours, is reading a comic book, his rump high in the air, his chin inches from the book. Suddenly, a wild rain of knocks on door fill the little room. Sonora Delgado, at the brasero drops a spoon with a clatter and Pedro springs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) Mamacita, let me in! Let me in, let me in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonora Delgado smirks knowingly and puts her hands on her hips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you love me, let me in -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimicking Teresa) Mamacita -- let me in. Let me in, now that I've spent half the night getting the corn meal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's coming -В— it's coming closer. I can see it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is afraid of the leopard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what she needs -- something to nip at her heels and hurry her up -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is interrupted by a scream so high, of such agonized finality,that it makes the others before it seem like not at all. Mingled with the scream and blurring the end of i comes an impact of such violence that the whole door structure shakes with it from top to bottom. A puff of du wells up around the door from the impact of the blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice high with fear) Madre do Dolores, she isn't fooling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pedro jumps to his feet. An instant change has come over face of Senora Delgado. She hurls herself forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beseechingly) Wait, Teresa! I come! I will let you in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senora Delgado tugs at the rusty bolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a moment, querida, hija do mi alma -- your mother is here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Senora Delgado tugs vainly at the bolt, Pedro darts ov to the fireplace and grabs up a stone from the hearth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother will let you in - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pedro rushes to the door and pushes his mother's hands as He hammers the unruly bar back with the stone. Then, he draws back and looks down at his feet. Senora Delgado's horrified eyes follow his glance. Under the crack of the door seeps a dark tongue of blood, widening and lengthening on the rough wooden floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of display window. The flowing blood dissolves into a film of water flowing across the window. The CAMERA PULLS BACK and we see a long handled squeegee down the left hand side of the window, clearing a strip o clear glass. Through this clear glass we look into C. T. Johnson's Undertaking Parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This shop occupies an ordinary store building. The displa window contains a solitary wreath of gilded leaves. Behin this wreath is a green baize curtain. The shop itself has sad air of unctuous gentility. On the left side of the ro are coffins on polished brass tressels. These coffins are half open to reveal the luxurious satin linings. In the b is a roll-top desk and swivel chair. In the rear of the s is a door leading to the embalming room. This is curtaine with the sane green baize. Over this whole interior is th eerie moire light that comes through the water-flowing window. Uncomfortable and stiff in their grief, we see the Delgad The fat Senora, the little boy and the father in his stif blue serge Sunday suit, stand near the wall. With them is nun in the sweet, sad costume of the Carmelite order. At other side of the room stands Kiki, somewhat abased, and ill at ease in the presence of the Delgados' grief. The window cleaner steps closer to the glass, lifts up hi long handled squeegee and opens up another strip beside t first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT of the doorway taking in the Delgado fami Senora Delgado is weeping, with tears running unchecked d her big flat cheeks. Her husband, unable to express his grief, stands twisting a cheap velour hat in work-gnarled hands. The little Delgado boy, unable to comprehend the finality of death is interested and quick-eyed, letting h glance rove from one object of interest to another, then suddenly bored, as is the manner of children, distracts himself by making the leopard shadow on the wall. From the other room we can hear, the sound of men's voice not clearly distinguishable, but growing in clarity. Kiki opens her purse, fumbles out a little soiled sheaf of bil and crosses the room. She hands the money to the nun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a half whisper) Sister, I'd like the family to have this -- might help with the funeral expenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nun smiles, nods her head and tucks the money up unde her sleeves. Kiki crosses back to the other side of the r Midway through this action, the voice in the other room h risen in volume and clarity so that we hear the coroner speaking. From behind the green baize curtain the words c in that solemn, yet routine fashion, which is the special of county clerks and other minions of the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...this evidence having been presented before me on this, the tenth day of April, I hereby declare that Teresa Guadalupe Maria Delgado was brought to her death by violence, resulting from the release of a wild animal, a leopard, purportedly on theatrical exhibition in this city -- Death by accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the last word is spoken, Jerry makes his appearance through the doorway. His face is drawn and earnest, reflecting the ordeal of looking at the mutilated remains the young girl. He crosses the room toward Kiki. MED. SHOT of Jerry as he takes his place beside Kiki. He looks at her as if seeking some comforting sign of friendliness. She keeps her eyes purposely averted from h MED. SHOT. Through the curtained doorway come the coroner Robles. The coroner carries a sheaf of papers in his hand Coming through the doorway quickly, he turns and seats himself at the desk in order to sign and seal these documents. Chief Robles, with his uniform cap in his hand, goes over the Delgado family. In his face we can see the sympathy a feeling he has for his fellow townsmen. Fe puts his arm a Delgado's shoulder and embraces him with that peculiar Mexican embrace in which the hand and arm thump the embraces's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, my friend. It is the will of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The genuineness of his sympathy and the sincerity of his voice take the banal touch from these simple words. Jerry looks on with interest. He turns to Kiki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) Suppose I slip them a few bucks В— for the funeral expenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be soft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls sharply at his arm to emphasize the point. He shrugs, abashed. From the inner room a fourth man comes out, a medium size gentleman in a light gray business suit with a felt hat i his hand. His face seems stiff and he walks a little bit unsteadily. Passing Jerry, he extends his hand and pats Jerry's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unfortunate accident. Nobody blames you, Mr. Manning. You mustn't feel badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry nods; not at all anxious for further condolences. Galbraith goes on to stand in the doorway. Robles leaves Delgado family and comes over to where Jerry and Kiki are standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can go now, Manning. There is no way we can hold you legally responsible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robles passes on a step or two, and then with a glance at Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That leopard's got to be found. I'm forming a posse. I can use help. -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the doorway, Galbraith answers quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry makes an impulsive move forward -- then stops himse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) I haven't done any posse work since last time I rode with Toni Mix at the old Bijou Theatre -- aged six, If you're interested,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not for me. (grinning) I'm literally and figuratively a tenderfoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts one foot and pats the ankle to illustrate his po Robles passes on and out of the doorway, Galbraith joinin him. With a backward look at the Delgado family, and a li hesitantly and slowly, Jerry and Kiki also leave the fune parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT - Jerry and Kiki as they stand in the cen of the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose he was trying to make me feel bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I suppose you don't feel bad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Jerry can protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was the other man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know В—В— a witness. He seemed to know something about animals -- you know -- expert testimony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he have to do -В— look at the body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all, had to look at the body. It was awful, Kiki -- awful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki makes a movement as if to put her hand comfortingly his sleeve, then changes her mind, dropping her hand. MED. SHOT - Undertaking Parlor - as the Delgado family emerges and starts down the street. The mother and father walk ahead, the father's arm about the mother's shoulder. They are followed by Pedro, his hand in the Nun's hand as they walk together. Kiki and Jerry fail to see them, and is necessary for Senor Delgado to ask for room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry and Kiki move hurriedly out of the way to let the little group of mourners go past. Jerry and Kiki stand watching them for a moment. CLOSEUP of Jerry, his expression betraying anxiety and indecision.

dialogues.speaker: INT CLO-CLO'S DRESSING ROOM
dialogues.text: LARGE HEAD CLOSEUP of Maria. The beautiful face of the fortune teller, coifed and framed in the folds of a shawl looks pure and MadonnaВ—like. Her downcast eyes add to th holy feeling. Then, suddenly, her hand comes up and puts lighted cigarette droopingly between her lips. The Madonn pose is shattered as though a stone had been thrown into still water. The CAMERA MOVES BACK to show Maria seated at Clo-Clo's dressing table, dealing out the cards. The last card to l her hand is the Ace of Spades. She gazes at it for a mome then hastily rakes up the deck and shuffles the cards. Behind her during this entire scene we have heard the tin of Moorish finger cymbals in metronome-like rhythm, the sounds spaced far apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That card again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - Clo-Clo and Maria. Clo-Clo is behind Maria. S has on a practice suit; black jersey leotards to the wais and a black silk bandeau about her breasts. She is using chair rail of the dressing room as a bar to practice a ba step while she beats out the slow rhythm of her exercise the Moorish finger cymbals. Maria again deals the cards a Clo-Clo continues to play and practice. There is a contrapuntal rhythm between the dealing of Maria's cards the slow tinkle of the cymbals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a mistake. It was a misdeal. I'll try once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cards "slapВ—slap' as she deals. As they fall, Maria speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a blackcard and bad card, but not the card of the cat -В— not the card of fourВ—footed things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw Teresa. Maybe I was the last to see her except perhaps her Mamacita and her little brother. I was going past --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still dealing) ) They buried Teresa today and they were hunting the leopard again -- out in the country this time. But they didn't get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're fools. Why don't they let Charlie How-Come hunt it alone. He's an Indian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All men are fools. They like to make a big show -В— shout and hunt --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is about to deal the last card, when she stops and lo at it, then sweeps up the deck without dealing the remain card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bad card again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did they say before the bad card came up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll meet a rich man and he will give, you money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disdainfully) You and your cards. Meet a rich man! I look for them with money. What rich man hasn't money. And for what was I born if it wasn't for money? You're not telling me anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a shrug) Watch and see, A day or a week - but certainly this month -- you will have money from a man and then-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) And then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will have to read the cards again. There was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shooing her out) You and your mistakes. Get out! I've got to dress for the supper, show and I don't want you to put the evil eye on me. Vamoose!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria unhurriedly snuffs out her cigarette, pockets her c and starts for the door. As she opens the door, we see Je Manning going past, dressed in slacks and sports shirt, carrying his coat over his arm. He is dusty and tired. Cl Clo looks after him with a malicious grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOT of Jerry as he knocks at Kiki's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you decent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From inside we hear Kiki's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door. We can see she is seated in the armcha and has a magazine in her hand which she has been reading She is dressed in street clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, does everybody love us now? You've been gone long enough to softВ—soap twenty editors!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without particular conviction) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drawling) And did you find the leopard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry realizes that Kiki is onto him. He gives her a look if to say, "So you knew." He bends down and starts brushi at his trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be the altitude В—В— you, bucking around the countryside with a lot of bootВ—andВ—saddle boys --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to explain) The whole town's in a state, Kiki В—В—doors locked, people huddling together like scared sheep В—В—nobody on the streets at night В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Our first real break -- and we throw wild animals at the audience

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. I'm buying a drink for a fellow who was on the posse with me, a nice guy. Come along he'll get a great kick out of meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki picks up her hat from the dressing table and goes to the door slowly. Jerry finishes brushing his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember the fellow this morning -- Galbraith. You've got time before the supper show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki joins him in the doorway and they start down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT of Eloise coming toward camera. She is in professional costume, and passes slowly along the front o the bar. She is smiling and opening a package of cigarett

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evidently at end of long recital) ..And it was sand, sand every foot of the way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eloise turns and the CAMERA TURNS WITH her. She stops at small table where Jerry, Kiki and Galbraith are seated. S hands the package of cigarettes to Jerry. (Note: Kiki is wearing her hat in this scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishing and paying for cigarettes) В—В—        As long as my feet held out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And not a sign of the leopard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith shakes his head, Jerry smiles his thanks to Elo She goes on out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry told me you were an expert with animals, Mr. Galbraith. Couldn't you tell where it went?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To know where that leopard went - В— I'm afraid you'd have to be a leopard and think like a leopard. I was a naturalist. That hardly qualifies me as an expert in hunting down lost leopards. I used to teach zoology in a little freshВ—water college back East. I gave that up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki is just normally curious, not conscious that she is prying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a little museum here in town. They've hired me to run it, We've some interesting exhibits of Indian arts and crafts. It's fun -- and I like living here in New Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you give up teaching?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a little pause) Various reasons. (switching the conversation) But I can't see why you'd be interested in the rather dusty career of William Galbraith В— teacher, naturalist, curator -- when you lead such a gay and exciting life yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wryly) Show business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It's always fascinated me. (confidentially) You know, once, when I was a youngster, I went to see Mrs. Leslie Carter in "Zaza." After the play I stood in the alley just to watch her come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both the younger people laugh at his unabashed simplicity

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kiki) So you see meeting you is a real thrill for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm hardly Mrs. Leslie Carter В—whoever she was. In fact, I'm not even much of a success around here  particularly after the backfire on Jerry's little publicity stunt with the leopard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was unfortunate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a hard look at Jerry) That was a calamity!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods her head toward the main door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT including the table and the door beyond. Through this doorway Clo-Clo emerges in her costume. She enters with the proud step of a reigning favorite. There light spatter of applause from the bar and the tables on porch. CloВ—Clo, taking the castanets from her bosom, beg walking toward the dancing space. Passing the table where Kiki, Jerry and Galbraith sit, she grins broadly end maliciously. Leaning slightly toward them she makes a derisive sound on her castanets, then stalks on. They fol her with their eyes as she starts down the steps. From th audience in the main portion of El Pueblo cafe comes the sound of brisk applause and CloВ—Clo's answering hail on castanets. Her dance music begins. Kiki starts getting up The two men rise with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she rises) Well, I'm next. You won't hear anything like that, Mr. Galbraith. (gesturing toward applause) I'm not a popular favorite since I let the leopard loose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with heavy gallantry) I'm sure if you are as talented as you are charming, Miss Walker, you have nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving off) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith starts to knock out his pipe on the heel of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd best be off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting a restraining hand on his forearm) I want to ask you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith looks at him questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about the leopard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're worrying about its killing someone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I want to go out and patrol the town - be everywhere at once - be sure nothing happens to anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. It's the way any decent man would feel in your position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know about animals -- their habits -- will it come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm quite sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry gives a little sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no danger at all. It's a wild animal. Do you think a wild animal prefers walls, streets and people when it can get into open country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terribly anxious to be convinced) That's right, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting toward the steps) Don't feel so concerned, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they descend the stops together, the CAMERA HAVING PAN LEFT to stay with them, now DOLLIES BEFORE them as they g down the path, toward the fountain. They come abreast of fountain and Galbraith pauses a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen a bit of life, and I have learned one thing. We are like that ball dancing on the fountain. We know as little about the forces that move us and move the world around us as that empty ball, which lives only because the water pushes it into the air, lets it fall and catches it again. You shouldn't feel too badly about Teresa Delgado.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - the fountain. We see the ball rising and fal В— oscillating in its movement. Clo-Clo is dancing, and although we can not see her, we c hear the click of her castanets, the quick, hard tread of feet. We catch an occasional glimpse of her shadow, as sh passes in dancing on the other side of the fountain.

dialogues.speaker: INT EL PUEBLO CAFE
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of the fountain. The jet of water has been tur off and the ball floats quietly on the surface of the innermost basin. MED. LONG SHOT of Clo-Clo, as she makes her way to the ga She is dressed in street clothes. Bus boys are busy pilin chairs onto the tables while two young maids are hosing d the tiles. Cigarette butts, bits of paper and ether odds ends of the night's trade litter the cafe and go swishing ahead of the streams of water. Clo-Clo smiles to one of the young maids as she passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long night, Chiquita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straightening up and shutting down the hose with her thumb) How long can a night be, Clo-Clo, when you spend it dancing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passing by) Twice as long as a day with your mop and pail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl laughs and lets the water of the hose spray out again. Clo-Clo goes on, out of the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUCKING SHOT of Clo-Clo as she walks wearily down the deserted street. She is smoking a cigarette. Swinging from one hand is the little ornamented chamois b in which she keeps her castanets. She comes to the flower store, sees that it is open and, throwing her cigarette a starts in.

dialogues.speaker: INT FLOWER STORE
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - Rosita, Senora Contreras' maid, has selected bouquet of long stemmed roses from a large tin bucket. As holds them aloft the flower vender, a chubby good-natured little Mexican in his late fifties, gently wraps a piece newspaper around the wet stems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the stems) Roses are like children -В— some have short legs and some long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flower vendor laughs loudly, his body vibrating. Rosi sees no humor in this remark and taking a coin from her pocket, hands it to him. Still chuckling, the vendor move his cash drawer, to make change. In the b.g., Clo-Clo can seen entering the store. She tiptoes forward directly beh the flower vendor and ignoring Rosita completely, snatche wilted gardenia from a tin. The flower vendor has caught action in the mirror and whirling, pulls the gardenia out her hand,and at the same time turns back to the cash draw CloВ—Clo isn't at all abashed by the vendor's action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't sell it - it's a day old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my stomach isn't a day old. If I don't sell flowers -- I don't eat -В— and I love to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo tries a new approach. Coyly she winks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell everybody you gave it to me, -- that will be good for your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, -- but bad for my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vendor drops the change into Rosita's hand, then turn on Clo-Clo, shoes her off with a motion. ANOTHER ANGLE В— taking in Rosita at edge of stall. She l off at Clo-Clo and with a grand gesture, pulls a long ste rose from the bouquet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mistress, Consuelo Contreras, does not have to beg for flowers. She won't miss one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosita flings a rose to Clo-Clo. Clo-Clo catches it. With snap she breaks the stem and thrusts the rose into her ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impudently) Thank the Senorita for me.

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT. The CAMERA PANS WITH Rosita as she hurrie crosses the street and mounting the opposite sidewalk, en the Contreras' home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a cool, shadowy square room. At the back is a stair The floor is tiled. Through an arched grilled doorway, we see the living room beyond. The front door opens and Rosi steps in hurriedly, her heels clicking on the tile floor. Three people are standing waiting. They are Senora Contre Cousin Felipe and Marta, an old servant who is more compa than maid in the household by this time. Marta is dressed in black -В— dress, shoes and apron. Her grey hair is dra back to a knot. She wears tiny gold loops in her pierced and a gold cross at the fastening of her high collar. Sen Contreras, a dignified, imposing woman with the remnants great beauty still apparent in her expressive eyes and lo hair, is dressed in a flowing lacy negligee. In her arms carries a little Chihuahua dog. Cousin Felipe is a dapper little cat of a man, meticulously dressed in the proper apparel of thirty years ago. The Senora and Cousin Felipe waiting on the stairs. Marta is in the hail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crossly) Shhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softening the rebuke, whispering) It will spoil the birthday song, Rosita, if we wake her too soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosita nods contritely. Walking with exaggerated care, sh joins them and they all start up the stairs. The CAMERA FOLLOWS them as they go upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOT of Senora Contreras, Marta and Rosita as they come u the landing and start on tiptoe toward a door. The Senora Contreras puts her hand on the knob softly. Cousin Felipe pulls a single rose from Rosita's armful. Marta sees him she glares but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although the curtains of the room are drawn, the softly filtered daylight shows this to be a room of delicacy and lightness. The simplicity of the white walls, the sheer curtains hanging across the barred, embrasured windows, t lovely lace coverlet and the pretty young-girl trinkets o the dressing table give the room an air of lightness. As the door swings inward, the sunlight fills the room. T we see, lying in the bed, serenely asleep, Consuelo Contreras. This is her eighteenth birthday. Senora Contreras walks to the foot of the bed and stands looking down at her daughter. She smiles sadly. In still, untroubled sleep, the full vulnerability of Consuelo's yo is touchingly apparent. Marta stands to one side, a little behind Senora Contrera Cousin Felipe remains in the background, near the open do Rosita tiptoes cautiously to the head of the bed and carefully puts down the roses, so that the blossoms lie i the curve of Consuelo's outflung arm. She has to drop on knee to do this and she stays in this position, slowly drawing her hands away from the flowers. They start singi "Las Mananitas" the traditional birthday song of Mexico - singing very softly at first. Consuelo stirs slightly and then opens her eyes. Lying as does, the first thing she sees are the roses, lying besid her. She lifts her eyes from the roses to see Rosita's eager smiling face, almost on a level with her own. Rosita's sm broadens but she goes on singing dutifully. Still bemused, but beginning to smile faintly herself, Consuelo looks beyond Rosita and sees Cousin Felipe stand back by the door. Very much the gallant, he touches his stolen rose to his lips and tosses it to Consuelo. Consuelo continues her survey of the room and turns her e to the foot of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily and lovingly) Madrecita!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senora Contreras nods slowly, but continues to sing with others as they go into the chorus. Consuelo starts to sit up, pulling the roses to her. Rosita gets up, too, and props the pillows behind her you mistress. Senora Contreras comes around the bed and sits the edge of it as the song finishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning on your birthday, Senorita Consuelo --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marta goes to one of the windows and motions Rosita to th other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a good morning, nina -- see how the sun is shining for you - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marta draws back the curtains and the room, already light seems to grow even lighter. Senora Contreras leans forwar and kisses Consuelo's forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a lovely way to wake up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks from the bouquet of roses to the single rose th Cousin Felipe threw onto the bed. She picks it up and hol it to her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is so beautiful, Cousin Felipe. Thank you for buying it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Consuelo's first words, Cousin Felipe begins to beam. he glances across the room and encounters Marts's grin, sardonic glance just as Consuelo says "How carefully you have picked it out!" Abashed, he murmurs something unintelligible and quietly slips out of the room. At the window, Rosita has been standing with her back to Marta, staring fixedly at Consuelo to attract her attenti She makes a little notion with her hands now and Consuelo glances at her. Smiling secretively, Rosita draws a white envelope part way out of her apron pocket, just enough to Consuelo see what it is. Then she hastily puts it out of sight again. There is a sudden light in Consuelo's eyes. is transfigured with a really exultant happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Had you forgotten that it was your birthday? I believe you had --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo gives a helpless little laugh of delight, throws arms around her mother end puts her head down against her mother's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so happy -- so happy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senora Contreras pats the girl's head fondly. Marta, leav the room, smiles at mother and daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning at the door) Rosita!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosita slowly walks away from the window and toward the d But as soon as Marta has gone out of the door, she stops the dressing table on the pretext of dusting the bottles her apron. Senora Contreras rises, with difficulty, and also goes to door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry now, my sweet, or we will be late for mass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Senora Contreras leaves the room, Rosita whirls around from the dressing table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Quick! Give it to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosita hands Consuelo the letter, Consuelo tears it open reads the few lines. From her expression, one sees that e the handwriting of her beloved fills her with happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will be waiting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eager to help) You must say that you went to take some of the roses to your father's grave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading the note again) At four. He will be there at four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to the window and looks out. CLOSE SHOT of Consuelo at window.        Beyond her we se dial on the wall.        It is seven o'clock and the shad thick and heavy in the morning quadrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The time will never pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a French window in the living room downstairs, Consuel pulling aside the heavy lace curtains and looking out. Be her we see the big sun dial and the shadows lie heavy in afternoon quadrant. It is nearly 5:00. She drops the curt and turns back into the room. MED. LONG SHOT - living room. Senora Contreras is half reclining in a chaise lounge. Consuelo is sitting on a pe point footstool beside the chaise lounge. Both of them ha embroidery frames in their hands. They are working on ver fine, sheer pillow cases,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) It seems to be getting darker in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senora Contreras glances over at the bright sunlight in t windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you afraid you will have a headache from working so long, Mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we don't work on these a little each day, they will never be done - and you will be a poor bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo looks at her mother curiously and a little apprehensively. Senora Contreras smiles but does not repl clock on the mantel strikes five in tiny bell tones. Cons looks at the clock desperately. Senora Contreras puts dow her embroidery frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is late, isn't it? Too late, I'm afraid, for you to go to the cemetery now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo jumps to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I must go to the cemetery, Mamas! It's my birthday -- I must!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senora Contreras studies the girl's troubled face. She reaches out her hand, takes Consuelo's hand and pulls the girl to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not come into this world a middleВ—aged widow, mi hijita...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo shakes her head in agreement -- but looks puzzle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything you think -- anything you do - - I thought and did before you. And my mother before me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo nods dutifully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are so young. I don't want you to look back on anything lacking in dignity, a few years from now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmuring) No, Mama --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally, young men will become interested in you. They should come here, to our house. They should be introduced to you by their parents or your Cousin Felipe or some other older relative -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo nods again. She glances uneasily at her mother a then her eyes go frantically to the clock. Senora Contrer lets go Consuelo's hand and leans back against the chaise lounge. She gives a little sigh of defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well -- get Rosita and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mama -- I'll hurry - I'll be right back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo leans over, kisses her mother hastily and then rushes out of the room. Senora Contreras looks at the doo through which Consuelo has passed. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUCKING SHOT - Consuelo and her maid are walking along t wall, quickly. Rosita is carrying the roses in her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (importantly) Pedro is waiting for me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly) Rosita В—В— I have wondered -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, senorita?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you are going to see Pedro, does your heart beat until you tremble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosita shrugs. Consuelo lifts one of the roses to her fac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once Raoul took my hand and pressed it to his cheek В—- so gently, so longingly. Suddenly I was afraid for him -- afraid of everything in the world that might hurt or sadden him. He saw the tears in my eyes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo is silent, her face ecstatic, remembering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost sullenly) Love is different for different people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly В— thoughtfully) I suppose so. I suppose it will be different for us, too В—В— when everyone knows. Then we will be just like other people. (smiles) But these last weeks will always be our secret В—В— a lovely secret to remember all our lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light is already dimming when Consuelo and Rosita com to the gates. In front of the ponderous wooden gates, fol back like great dark wings, stands the gatekeeper of the cemetery. Fe is a very tall, incredibly thin, old man, dressed in a tight black alpaca suit. He has built a litt fire in the gutter and stands warming himself by it. In h hands is an unfinished wooden necklace which he is carvin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurriedly) I will see you back at the house, Senorita...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo nods and Rosita hurries away down the street. Th gatekeeper looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late today, Senorita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have brought my birthday flowers for my father's grave -- it will only take a moment - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time is strange. A moment can be as short as a breath --or as long as eternity -- don't linger - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo starts through the gates, not paying any attenti to the old man's words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after Consuelo) The gates are locked at six --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no reply. The old man shrugs his shoulders and hunches over his little Lire again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headstone of Don Rafael Contreras' grave, white stone with a bronze wreath, is shadowed by the failing light of sunset. The headstone reads: INSERT        RAFAEL CONTRERAS y GARCIA

dialogues.speaker: PRAY FOR HIS SOUL
dialogues.text: BACK TO SCENE. Consuelo's flowers lie across the grave. Consuelo is half kneeling, half sitting beside the grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low, but speaking perfectly naturally and conversationally) And so you must forgive me, father, for deceiving mother. She will meet Raoul soon -- and everything will be as you would wish. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo rises and crosses to a near-by path. She looks i the growing shadows of the cemetery -- then up into the trees. Only the tops of them are lighted by the last rays the sunset.

dialogues.speaker: EXT PATH LEADING TO BELVEDERE IN CEMETERY
dialogues.text: Consuelo hurries along a path, with trees and graves on either side.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BELVEDERE IN CEMETERY
dialogues.text: Just off the path is a little belvedere, a circular hedge spaced at intervals by Grecian columns. Inside, a marble bench curves half-way around the hedge. Consuelo approach it. Seeing the belvedere empty, she looks puzzled. She st into the belvedere and then turns back and looks into the lowering gloom of the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncertainly) Raoul? ... Raoul...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo waits, Her face is filled with disappointment an the first faint uneasiness of apprehension as the silence continues. She turns back into the belvedere.

dialogues.speaker: INT BELVEDERE
dialogues.text: On the ground a number of partly smoked cigarettes have b stamped out -В— and another lies on the marble bench. Con picks it up and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the inside of the cemetery, we see one of the wooden gates swinging closed,
