dialogues.speaker: EXT GATES OF CEMETERY
dialogues.text: The Gatekeeper is laboriously pulling the other gate clos Suddenly, he stops.  He pushes the gate back open a littl way and, standing in the opening, takes        a whistle pocket and puts it to his lips. It has a high, thin, quavering sound.

dialogues.speaker: BELVEDERE IN CEMETERY
dialogues.text: Consuelo is seated on the marble bench, her posture dejec lost in thought. In the distance, the whistle sounds fain She does not stir.

dialogues.speaker: EXT GATES OF CEMETERY
dialogues.text: The Gatekeeper gives two mere short blasts on the whistle

dialogues.speaker: INT BELVEDERE IN CEMETERY
dialogues.text: Consuelo raises her head as the quavering notes sound in distance. For a moment, she looks puzzled -- then her eye widen in horrified recognition of the sound. She jumps to feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo steps out of the inclosure. She looks up into th tree tops. They are only darkness now, merging with the almost complete darkness of the sky above. Consuelo runs the path.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GATES OF CEMETERY- NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Gatekeeper stands listening for a moment and then continues pulling the gate toward him until it clicks shu with the other gate. He drops the whistle into his coat pocket and, from the same pocket, pulls out a large key. turns it in the lock of the gate. He turns around and mov toward the street and his little gutter fire. His shadow moves enormously on the gate.

dialogues.speaker: EXT MAIN AVENUE OF CEMETERY
dialogues.text: We see Consuelo running down a broad avenue in the cemete

dialogues.speaker: EXT GATES OF CEMETERY
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT of the closed cemetery gates. The Gatekeep has disappeared. The little fire burning away in the empt street makes the loneliness of the scene more apparent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panting, Consuelo flings herself against the closed gates tugging at the handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me out! Help В—В— helps! Let me out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking desperately anxious, Consuelo turns. She looks ac the cemetery and then starts running back up the main ave

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the head of the avenue, several paths fan out in a hal circle. Consuelo stands looking from one to another. She chooses the center oath and runs into the treeВ—thickened darkness

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo runs at breakneck pace down a path. On either si are box hedges taller than she is.

dialogues.speaker: EXT FORKED PATH
dialogues.text: The path Consuelo is on splits into two paths. In the V o the fork is a single grave and over it hovers a tall shaf marble carved in the likeness of a brooding angel with fo wings and bowed head. Consuelo locks about frantically an then leans against the base of the statue, gasping for breath. Suddenly a wind springs up and the silence is bro into a thousand rustles and murmurs as the wind stirs thr the trees. Consuelo shivers and slowly lifts her head to up toward the tree tops. She looks directly up into the f of the statue. CLOSEUP of the angel's face is curiously sinister because there is light touching its contours. Consuelo whirls about to find the source of light. Throug the wind-stirred branches she sees the great, lopВ—sided just rising into the night. She stumbles away from the statue and down the rightВ—han path, walking a few steps, then running a few steps, tryi to force herself to rush on. Consuelo stands looking down into the old burial ground, depression filled with weed-grown graves and ancient wood headstones, either crazily askew or down entirely. It is entirely surrounded by the tall trees of the cemetery В—В the moonlight seems to fill the place with mist. Consuelo starts down the slope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no paths here. The weeds grow solidly across th ground В— except where a grave, here and there, has falle and its earth is broken into clods. Consuelo stumbles abo aimlessly. As she crosses one of the mounds, her foot str a fallen wooden marker. It is rotten and the green light phosphorescene flashes across it,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving again between tall trees, Consuelo moves on, no lo able to run. But when she sees a whiteness between the tr ahead of her, she does spur herself forward more rapidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo flings herself against the wall, her face alight with hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling loudly) Help! Help! Help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is silence. Slowly, keeping her hands pressed again the wall and moving sideways, Consuelo goes alongside the wall until she comes to a tree growing very close to the wall. In fact, one massive bough extends out over the wal and Consuelo looks up at it hopefully.  Then her expressi changes В— becomes tense. CLOSE SHOT of Consuelo.  Her eyes are wide and frightened From the other side of the wall comes a sound В— a light, scratching sound, exactly the same sound as that heard by Teresa Delgado in her first trip through the underpass tunnel. Listening intensely, Consuelo turns her head unti her ear is pressed against the wall. Now, we hear the sou more distinctly В— as she is hearing it В— but it is stil light, feathery sound. Then, suddenly, it ceases. And as Consuelo strains to hear it again, there is the sharp, ho clap of a car door carelessly flung shut just outside the wall. It is followed by the grind of a car starter. Consu jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait В—В— wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car motor starts. Pressing herself against the wall, Consuelo screams again and again. Finally, as the unseen starts to slip away, the roar of its motor subsides and a that moment Consuelo's scream sounds clearly. Brakes rasp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello -В— who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo is breathing in such convulsive gasps that she cannot emit any sound for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) Here! I'm in here behind the wall!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the sound of a car door being opened, and then footsteps beyond the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been locked in. Please get me out -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, don't get panicky. I'll climb over and get you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pressed tightly against the wall, Consuelo listens. She h running footsteps and then the thud of someone jumping up the wall, trying to get over it with a running start. Onc twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't make it. You wait there and I'll get someone to lend me a ladder - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the sound of the car door banging shut again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantically) No, don't leave me! Don't go away В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're all right now. It's just a matter of a few minutes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't forget В—В— you'll come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay just where you are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roar of the motor fills the scene again. Then it is q

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be back before you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the sound of the car drawing away. The sound of lessens, fades В— is swallowed in renewed silence. Consue stands against the wall, motionless. She turns fearfully, that her back is to the wall, and peers into the shadows. Suddenly she stiffens. CLOSE SHOT of Consuelo. Her eyes widen. She turns her hea that her ear is close to the wall. And again we hear the curious scratching sound, and with it, another sound В—-- soft, living, breathing sound, as of animal nostrils snuffling along the wall, searching the scent of prey. Th is a brief silence, and then Consuelo's head snaps up as hear a soft padding sound near the top of the wall. She s only the moon, just visible in the space between the tree bough and the top of the wall. There is nothing to be see but a rustling sound comes from the top of the wall. Consuelo's eyes are motionless, fixed on the bough overhe Very gradually, the great bough lowers, blotting the moon from view. Consuelo presses her back against the wall, as she would push herself into it, escape through it. Her he thrown back, is motionless В— her eyes watching the omino movement of the great bough, are motionless. And as she stares, a spasm of terror contorts her face. The bough suddenly springs back and the moon can be seen for one instant. During that instant we hear simultaneously a low horrible snarl and a scream. Both are cut off as the whol scene blacks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HIGH ANGLE SHOT through the branches of a great tree overhanging the wall shows a scene of sad activity. Consuelo's body, covered with a light canvas sheet, lies at the foot of the tree.  Five ladders, three against the outside wall, two against the inside wall, form a curious pattern of bars and stripes in the clean morning sunlight Uniformed policemen and plainВ—clothesmen bustle about. O them is making a moulage of footprints, his little workin space roped off with twine and stakes  Others are examini the tree. Two policemen, one uniformed, stand at the side and betwe them stands a young man dazed and broken, almost hanging the grip of the officers. He is sobbing. This is Raoul Belmonte. Suddenly he screams out hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Why? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The policemen gently shake him into silence. Robles, followed by Galbraith and Jerry come up over the ladders. Robles climbs down the inside ladder as does Galbraith, but Jerry, being younger, leaps down. MED. CLOSE SHOT В— SHOOTING TOWARD the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying out) Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robles looks over questioningly. The uniformed policeman, Mexican, answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: El novio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost simultaneously) The boy friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not unkindly) Shut that man up. Take him out of here or give him something to keep him quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the two officers lead Belmonte away, Jerry looks after - his face deeply troubled. The three men then turn towar the shrouded body. A police officer, an American with a lieutenant's bars an his shoulders, stands at the head of corpse. He bends down, lifts up the canvas, and Robles an Jerry peer under for a brief minute. Galbraith does not l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The leopard again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any witnesses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just secondary witnesses -В— the man who Was coming to help her out -- the man he borrowed the ladder from - - they found the body --and the gatekeeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gatekeeper, who has been standing near one of the policemen, takes a half step forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I warned her. I told her the gates would be closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quieting him) That's all right, paisano, it's not your fault, we know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man shuffles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lieutenant) Anything else -В— clues?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant points to a square cardboard box on the ground. Galbraith picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the leopard all right. A broken claw --        some black hairs -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There arc claw marks on the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross to the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have made these getting out. Notice the way they've been dug in from above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the ground) And these leaves. They don't fall this time of year. They must have shaken down on her when it jumped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry has been looking from one bit of evidence to the ot puzzled. He turns to Galbraith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc -- something you said the other day --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't jibe with this В—В— you told me the leopard would go out into the country В—- it wouldn't stay in the city В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure -- certainly В—- but what's that got to do with this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little hesitantly) That's what I don't understand -- why should it come here -- and why didn't it stay here? It's got trees and bushes here -- outside nothing but cement and asphalt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little impatient) Jerry, I talked to you about the habits of an ordinary wild leopard. This leopard is another matter entirely - - a caged animal travelling around with Charlie How Come for years and years.. That's why it kills human beings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't know how to hunt its natural prey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it doesn't eat what it kills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caged animals are unpredictable. They're like frustrated human beings. I can't answer your question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why it just mauls and tears at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's wrong with this whole setup --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, there is something wrong. People who want publicity and don't mind how they get it --what risks they make other people run - - what agony and sorrow they bring to other people --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know all that, chief, and I don't like it any better than you do, but there's something else --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robles is about to reply. Galbraith stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, Robles. (indicating Jerry) Let him go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can understand about the cat killing the first girl. Charlie How Come told me. All that noise and those lights -- scared crazy it would do anything. Last night there was nothing to disturb it. Just a little girl alone in a cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you getting at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing much -- just that it might not be a cat this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robles smiles, Galbraith shakes his head. Jerry starts fo the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - Charlie How-Come's truck. Charlie is standing the tailboard of the truck with a rubber exerciser in his hands. Beside him is an empty cage. He is giving his spie but has only managed to attract an audience of small Mexi boys who obviously have not a dime among the dozen of the Jerry is standing by watching him, obviously waiting for to finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spieling) Health - - vigor -- vitality -- s-t-r-e-t-c-h -- (suiting the action to the word) ...s t r e t c h. Watch the panther! Watch the lion in the jungles! What do they do -- s-t-r-e t-c-h. (quieter and more confidential tone) Strength -- strength and vitality. Here I can sell you the secret of the cat's strength -- the cat's vitality. Only a dollar. Only a dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group of small boys, sensing that this is the end of show, have already started to disappear. Charlie climbs stiffly down from the truck and faces Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't make a buck without my leopard. I tell you, Mr. Manning, you gotta find that cat for me -- or pay up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Charlie, just be patient. I'll fix everything. You don't want that cat, anyway. It killed two people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) No, sir. That girl in the cemetery? My cat didn't kill that girl. I told you cats don't go around looking for trouble. If that cat's alive, it's out in the country hiding under a bush, starving to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested, but concealing it) You really think so, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That cat ain't mean. I feed him out of my own hand for six years. Why don't he kill me? At night in the truck, I let him out of the cage. When I am falling asleep I hear him walking back and forth. I go to sleep. He don't hurt me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all say the cat killed this second girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't say it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like one of them to say it to you, Charlie. I'd like to have you hear his side of it his reasons. Want to hear them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his elbow) Let's get in your truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They climb into the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up at the museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie puts his foot on the starter and the motor coughs wheezes into reluctant activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The museum is built on a hilltop and from the portico we overlook the sagebrush and mesquite-covered hills of New Mexico, rolling away to the horizon. At one end of this o porch an old Indian hand loom has been set up and here an Indian woman in Zuni costume sits patiently weaving a rug the shuttle flying back and forth monotonously, and the f pedal creaking as she changes threads. Charlie and Jerry into the portico and cross to the door. They push open th heavy bronze door and enter the museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This museum, probably erected with the aid of government funds, is well-proportioned and severely plain. A portico long, rectangular display room and a combined office and workshop in an alcove off the main room comprise the muse The display room has glass showcases containing various Indian artifacts. On the walls are examples of Indian rug blanket weaving, masks and ceremonial properties. Galbraith's workshop is completely practical. A trestle t with an office armchair behind it, book shelves and trans cases containing labeled shards and artifacts are in this alcove. On the trestle table, which Galbraith uses as a d is a reading glass on a fixed stand which he uses to exam specimens. Charlie and Jerry walk in. Charlie has evidently been her before because he shuffles down the main aisle through th display room without looking around. Jerry keeps pace wit him but glances from side to side at various pieces. At t end of the museum they turn and enter the little alcove w Galbraith is seated at his desk. He is sharpening a penci and does not look up. They wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) Why, hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up, comes around the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Charlie How-Come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're old friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jerry) Come to look around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More or less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take you about. Got some nice things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts off and they follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they walk) Charlie and I were talking. That's one reason I wanted to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at him) About Charlie's leopard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have reached the display room and pause a moment. Fr this point on, the CAMERA TRUCKS WITH them as they go. Galbraith acts as cicerone, conducting them about, walkin ahead of them as he displays the exhibits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) Here is something that should interest Charlie - a stone leopard head made by his ancestors some six hundred years ago. They used it in ceremonies. The jaguar -- in fact all the cat family -- were considered the personification of force and violence in their religious rites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squinting at it) It don't look like a leopard to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk on. Jerry has paid no attention to the exhibit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie doesn't think the leopard killed the girl in the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning, with a smile) Charlie likes his leopard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I like my leopards

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he admitted quick enough that it killed the first girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently) Well, Charlie, just why do you think your cat didn't kill the Contreras girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know -- not scared enough. Nothing to scare it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If a leopard didn't do it, who did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be. Why would a man kill her? For what? It wasn't robbery. It wasn't a crime of jealousy or passion. She had no enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are all sorts of men. You get to see some funny ones as a reporter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sagely) I can understand what you mean - demented men, pathological cases. But what sort of man would kill like a leopard and leave the traces of a leopard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some crazy guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he would have to know about leopards - have access to leopard claws and hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk on. Galbraith points out a nicely molded jug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's our prize exhibit - an artifact of the Paleolithic period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks into the case with a glance almost of affection, then turns back to Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had given up digging in a certain barrow. I went back and I tried again. I just had a hunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) A hunch -- that's all I've got about this leopard thing. It's just a hunch, yet I feel it deep in the stomach. It was a man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but what sort of a man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning toward Charlie chuckling) You, Charlie -- you know leopards. You might have had an old claw around somewhere, and perhaps a bit of hair from the cage -В— eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing the joke, with a wide grin) Sure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm serious about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still smiling) Oh, I'm only exploring your theory. Let's take a step further. You drink, don't you, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when you drink, you get drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sleep it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But between the time you leave the cant ma and fall into bed in that old truck of yours, what happens, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping near the door) That's just it, Charlie. That's what I'm driving at. You could do anything in that time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie wasn't drunk last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very worried) Yes, I was drunk, Mr. Manning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith makes a gesture with his arms as if to say "The you are." Charlie shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a wide friendly smile) See? There's a suspect for you, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry looks over at Charlie, who is very woebegone, worri and nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his arm, kidding) Come on, Charlie. Let's go find another and better suspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to see the rest of the exhibit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some other time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men nod to each other. Jerry leads Charlie out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Jerry come out of the museum and stand for a moment on the edge of the steps. Behind there the Indian woman continues working at her loom, the heavy shuttle go back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching into his pocket) Here have a cigarette. He was only kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he wasn't kidding. I'm sick. Claw women? Hurt little girls? No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry is still holding the cigarette out toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I want to see Robles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to see him for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want him to lock me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Charlie, you didn't do it, and you know you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I want him to lock me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts forward and Jerry goes with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's truck is parked at one corner. He, Jerry and Ro stand in front of it talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doc's right. I don't know what I do when I get drunk. I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is crazy, Charlie. You know you didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better lock me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been trying to tell him, Sheriff. He won't listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get one thing clear. Did Galbraith make a direct accusation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He was kidding Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better lock me up. If I do things like that I want to be put away. I don't want to hurt nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes his arm) All right, Charlie. If it will relieve your mind, I'll put you away for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT -Charlie holding on to some cell bars, st brooding. O.S., we hear the sound of castanets. Charlie l his head to look out of an unseen window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUCKING SHOT - Clo-Clo, dressed in dancing costume, with black shawl over it, passes along the street, clicking he castanets idly. From afar we hear a sad, sweet Mexican lo song, being sung in a high tenor voice. Clo-Clo passes a dimly lit doorway, and we see a woman sprinkling holy water on the door step from a font that h beside the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valganos Dios.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes the sign of the cross and softly closes the doo Further down the street, two policemen pass CloВ—Clo, wal in step. She grins at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men for one beat? Afraid of the big cat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Sure. I've got a family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass on. The CAMERA FOLLOWS CloВ—Clo. The love song grown louder and clearer and now we come to its source. A young boy is perched on ton of some vegetable crates on a old truck parked alongside the curb. He is singing for hi own pleasure and hardly notices Clo-Clo as she passes. Smiling, she lifts one pair of castanets to follow the be of his song. He waves to her and she passes on into the  darkness beyond the truck. The CAMERA HOLDS for a moment on the young boy as the castanets, playing the rhythm of his song, fade away in t distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patio is pretty well filled with patrons. Clo-Clo, crossing the patio from the entrance gates to the bar in rear, skirts the dance floor В—- watching the customers w amusement. In doing so, she almost bumps into a waiter wi full tray. To let him pass, she backs aside and stands by of the tables. At this table are three people; John Brunton, his daughte Helene and her husband, Dwight. John Brunton is a heavyВ—set, rather impressive looking m about sixty  Because he is an older man with the air of authority which comes from success and money, you have to look twice to catch both the gaiety and the gentle irony his eyes. Helene and Dwight are two of his closest reason for that irony. They are nice-looking, wellВ—groomed, som conventionally smart people. Waiting for the waiter to go by, Clo-Clo half turns and l down at the three people. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helene looks up coolly at Clo-Clo and then reaches for he cigarette case. Dwight, with a faint smile which is inten to put brash women in their places, busies himself lighti Helene's cigarette. Brunton looks up at Clo-Clo end gives a friendly smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo continues on her way to the bar, without looking back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fretfully looking at his wristwatch) It's been half an hour since we ordered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's have a drink while we're waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brunton leans back a little and cranes his neck to see if can locate the waiter. Helene puts her hand over his on t table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Don't bother. I don't want one -В— do you, Dwight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight, disinterested, shrugs his shoulders. Helene gives one of those say-something-dope looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hastily) No В—- no, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music has stopped and the dancers applaud in the brie pause, Then the orchestra starts again -- this time a tan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightening) Want to dance, Helene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging her, shoulders) I suppose so --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she starts to rise, he gets up to pull back her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight rises from the table and the two of them walk over the dance floor. Brunton watches them as they go off. The walks away, in the direction of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a crowd of people are standing around the bar, eith waiting for their drinks or drinking them there. Others a seated at the small tables here and there on the veranda houses the bar. At a table quite near the steps leading d to the patio, Clo-Clo is seated. A tall, thin goblet of b stands in front of her. Brunton starts up the steps.. Seeing him, Clo-Clo grabs t beer and puts it on the floor between her chair and the veranda railing. Then she starts looking toward the bar, if waiting for someone to wait on her. As Brunton comes to the top of the steps Clo-Clo just "happens" to catch his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) Hello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning on the charm and the gamin grin) I think we are playing tag -- or maybe hide-and-seek, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brunton steps over to her table and stands with his band the back of the unoccupied chair - - a little uncertainly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is someone with you -- can I get you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helene and Dwight are seated at the table again. A waiter serving the dinner they hate been waiting for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savagely) It's taken this        impossible trip to show me what an old fool father has become!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight rises from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll look for him. He's probably in the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brunton is now seated at the little table with Clo-Clo. N them, a waiter is preparing to open a bottle of champagne from an ice bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the waiter) Just a moment (to CloВ—Clo) Look В—- you've ordered this stuff like a sensible girl --but you don't have to drink it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CloВ—Clo studies him, a little warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want it? Or do you want another beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over the side of the table and gently nudges the hidden goblet with the toe of his shoe, For a moment CloВ is startled В— then she begins to grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the waiter) Two beers -- big ones!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brunton looks off toward the steps. An expression of dism comes over his face. CloВ—Clo turns around to see Dwight coming up to them. Dwight looks from Clo-Clo to the unope champagne В—- and then smiles at his father-inВ—law with disagreeably "understanding" smirk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've finally gotten around to our dinner --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shortly) I'll be there In a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nasty-nice) Sorry -- but you know how Helene is -- she's been worrying about you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still smiling, Dwight turns away. Clo-Clo looks after him then straightens around and faces Brunton again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sonВ—inВ—law. What do you think of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flippantly) That depends. How much money has he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brunton studies her -- not disapprovingly, but as he woul study a child or an animal that appealed to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you marry champagne, Clo-Clo, you can't trade it in for beer. You're stuck with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't understand that fancy talk. (excitedly) You mean I'm a gold-digger? Sure, I'm a gold-digger -- why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (echoing her calmly) Why not -- if you like it В—- if that's what you really want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo sniffs angrily. The waiter serves the two glasses beer. CloВ—Clo grabs hers and gulps thirstily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should just forget all about money - - forget about mamma and the kids and the rent, huh - marry some poor dope like -- oh, like Carlos Dominguez - - and get fat and В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Who's Carlos Dom-what's-his-name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CloВ—Clo shrugs her shoulders in a dramatic gesture of indifference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody. A boy who works in a grocery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching her) Good looking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MmmВ—В—В—yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice fellow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again Clo-Clo shrugs her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he in love with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CloВ—Clo looks down at her glass of beer, sullenly. Brunt watches her, not saying anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a sudden outburst) Why do you ask so many questions? What difference does it make how Carlos and I feel? Feeling does not buy clothes and houses!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kindly) Drink your beer and don't get so excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In spite of herself, Clo-Clo starts smiling. Brunton smil back at her and lifts his glass of beer. She lifts hers t touch it in salute. The Brunton's table. The younger Bruntons are half-way through dinner. He looks at his watch. She frowns. She rises and he helps her on with her stole. John Brunton is still seated at the little table. He is laughing and coughing from the exertion of the laughter. Clo stands behind him, thumping him on the back. She look worried. Several people in the bar are watching them with amusement -- but a nice kind of amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll kill yourself. Isn't there something sad we can talk about, just until you get over this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brunton wipes the tears of laughter from his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we were supposed to be doing this time. But the sadder you try to be, the funnier it comes out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brunton makes a little face and then turns around to see Helene who is coming coward him from the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furiously) We finished dinner hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brunton gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) All right. I'll be with you as soon as I've settled this В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves his hand at the glasses on the little table. With a fishy eye for Clo-Clo, Helene turns and goes back the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you let her boss you around like that? Give her a good slap and tell her to keep still!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brunton chuckles. He takes some change from his pocket an puts it down on the little table. The waiter from the pat comes up the stairs and hands him the bill on a plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame will be waiting at the entrance -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brunton looks at the bill and then reaches into an inner pocket for a wallet. He takes a couple of greenbacks from and hands them to the waiter. The waiter bows and smiles goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) Madame will be waiting -- Madame ought to go on waiting! To have such a father and treat him like a poor cousin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brunton smiles again -- he starts to put his wallet away then opens it up again and takes a single bill from anoth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: compartment. He puts it in Clo-Clo's hand and folds her fingers over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for "mama and the kids."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking at the bill; kidding) What about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get your money from your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CloВ—Clo stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos What's-His-Name -- the boy at the grocer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo looks at him questioningly for a moment В—- then suddenly puts her arms around his neck and kisses his che Brunton, greatly touched, pats her shoulder. They smile a each other -- and then Brunton turns and walks away. Clo-Clo looks after him, then down at her hand. She lifts fingers from the bill crushed in her palm. Her eyes widen shocked amazement. INSERT        $100 bill, crumpled in her hand -- The fing on it again. BIG HEAD CLOSE-UP - Clo-Clo. She smiles happily and start off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo is scurrying down the street as fast as her stilt heeled pump will carry her. Her face is bright with excitement and she hums to herself, snapping her fingers imitation of her castanets. She passes the flower shop an then the window of the store where Maria tells fortunes. Clo hesitates -- goes back and peers through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior of the store is dismal. On one wall hangs a phrenological chart. In the center of the room is a plain kitchen table with two rickety chairs, one of them a bent affair with a sagging cane seat. On the table sleeps a wh cat, curled up against a cracked crystal ball. A cheap th restaurant saucer on the table is more than halfВ—filled cigarette butts and ashes. Maria is seated at the table. A cigarette is in her mouth She just sits there, not touching the deck of cards in fr of her В—В— staring across at the wall. There is the sound of the door opening and Maria looks up She says nothing as Clo-Clo comes into the place, but wai until Clo-Clo stands beside the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- did he give you a lot of money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elderly man I told you about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo shrugs her shoulders and sits down at the table,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was old enough -- but you slipped up on the money. Try it again, why don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria looks at her sardonically, but obligingly picks up deck of cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your wish in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo shuffles thorn a few times and then hands them to Maria. Maria cuts them into seven piles, face down. She starts turning up the top card on each pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up at Clo-Clo who maintains a completely blank  expression. Clo-Clo smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe a honeymoon --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria starts to turn up the next card, with a practiced r of the wrist В—- as she sees what it is, however, she dro and quickly swirls all the cards together again and hands pack to Clo-Clo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astounded) What are you doing that for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria shrugs her shoulders. Clo-Clo cuts the deck into th sections. Maria starts turning the top cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmuring) Again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo looks down at the cards, perplexed because Maria perplexed. She sees a ten of diamonds followed by a four spades. The third pile is still untouched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something black В—- something on its way to you В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria stares down at the third pack and then, with a deft twist, flips the top card face up. Almost simultaneously, Maria slaps her hand over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Don't look at it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Let me see it В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, seemingly reluctantly, Maria uncovers the card. INSERT        The Ace of Spades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The death card - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not - cards mean different things different times --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo just stands there, staring down at the card. Clo-Clo nods her head slowly. She lays some silver on the table in payment for the reading, then goes across the ro to the door. Maria stands up and walks over to join her. Clo stands looking out of the door. She turns abruptly to Maria, at her elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk a little ways with me В—-?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria shrugs her shoulders. CloВ—Clo starts out the door, Maria behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo and Maria walk in silence past the doorway where Shorty blew the smoke ring, past the perch where the boy girl were kissing -- past the dark Delgado house. CloВ—Cl glances up at the window as they go by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sidewalk is so high above the street here that there three stone steps set in the curb. Clo-Clo goes down the steps, but Maria stops at the top. CloВ—Clo turns and loo at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria says nothing, Just stands there with an odd, mockin little smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CloВ—Clo continues across the street and up the curb step the other side. At the top of those steps, she turns and looks back. The corner where she had left Maria is now em The moonlit street stretches deserted on either side. Clo hurries on again, almost running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a nice residential section, more American in feel than the other streets we have seen. There are trees on either side of the street and the moonlight makes lacy patterns through them. A shoulder-high brick wall enclose the garden of the house on the corner. Clo-Clo is walking along this brick wall. A purr of sound quickly lifts to t sound of a high-powered motor and the glare of headlights precede a long, low black roadster. The car comes around corner and stops. A young man leans out on the driver's s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, chiquita, want a lift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo stops and eyes him speculatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What way are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your way В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo suddenly shrinks back, horror coming into her eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your car В—В— what color is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo backs up against the brick wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrilly) Get outta here! Get away from me with that thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dumbfounded) What do you mean -В— "thing"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo starts running along the wall, looking back in te over her shoulder. The young man looks after her dumbfoun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a small, ordinary clapboard house. In front of it a scraggly, dusty attempt at a lawn and garden. A mongrel lies on the dusty path sleeping.  Suddenly he leaps up an barks sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be still, Pancho!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo walks up the path to the house. She opens the fro door, pushes Pancho away with her foot and slips        i house, closing the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the shadowy light of a single candle, Clo-Clo's small bedroom can be seen only dimly. In it are a bed with iron bedstead, an ancient wooden rocking-Chair, a chest of drawers, and a little child's bed. The candle stands in a saucer on top of the chest. A little girl is sleeping in large bed. Clo-Clo comes into the room.  She sits down on the edge o the bed and pulls the little girl into her arms. The chil murmurs sleepily and snuggles up to Clo-Clo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily) Pepita, tomorrow..I'm going to buy you the most beautiful silk dress in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little girl tries to open her eyes, but the lids flut closed again and the child goes on sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing softly) You don't believe me, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lays the child in the smaller bed and pulls up the fu ruffled skirt of her costume..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait until you see what I have В— then you'll wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs her finger under the rolled top of one of her si stockings. She looks startled. Then, she stands up and pu the costume back over the other leg. She looks in that stocking roll. She stands stricken under the realization she has lost the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that you Gabriela? What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo doesn't answer. She scuffs off her shoes and look them. She drags off the long stockings, standing first on leg and then the other. She turns them inside out and sha them. Clo-Clo's mother appears in the doorway. She is a prematu -aged woman with her hair in two braids and wearing a tor wrapper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Have you lost something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tensely) Yes. Money. I must have lost it in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo thrusts her feet into the slipper, not bothering put the stockings on again. She grabs up a shawl from the foot of the bed and throws it over her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going out again, hijita? Why don't you stay home and rest -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CloВ—Clo stops to kiss her mother's forehead and then goe swiftly out the door, past her. The Mother turns to follo her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently) Gabriela!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo walks into the scene very slowly, scanning every of the sidewalk, from the curb to the brick wall and back again, over and over as she moves toward the corner. She retraces the pattern of her steps when she stopped to tal the Young Man -- out to the curb В—В— back to the wall an along the wall to the corner. She        then turns the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clo-Clo looks down her side of this street. She looks acr the street. CloВ—Clo half turns, as if to retrace her ste but just then something further down the sidewalk catches eye. She runs along the wall and leans down to grab at th bit of folded green and white paper there. The elation di from her face. Stonily, rigidly she stares at it, the wra from a stick of gum. There is a tiny sound -- no more than a flicker of sound. CloВ—Clo lifts her face slowly. There is no movement anyw no further sound. Clo-Clo looks to the building. There ar alternate bands of black darkness and moonlight. CloВ—Clo eyes move from one to another. There is no movement behin any of them. Frowning a little, Clo-Clo starts back toward the corner. she moves, she hears footsteps across the street in the b shadows. Listening, she walks more softly. But there is n fear in her expression        or her posture. She is only Suddenly, she whirls and looks across the street. There i nothing over there, nothing moving, nothing making sound. walks on to the corner arid, looking back once, goes on around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CloВ—Clo walks away from the corner, along the brick wall very slowly. Her eyes go from side to side and she turns head slightly, as she listens. She stops. Behind her, bac around the corner, she hears footsteps В—- and then an imitative silence. She takes a few more s stops suddenly again -В— and again the pursuing footsteps overlap hers. As Clo-Clo stands there, the silence is protracted. Puzzled, but still showing no expression or gesture of fear, Clo-Clo listens, then smiles and turns b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling; speaks softly) Carlos В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets as far as the corner, throws away her cigarette takes a compact and lipstick from her pocket. She holds u the compact mirror and starts to outline her lips with th lipstick. BIG CLOSEUP В— CloВ—Clo. There is a tiny sound - and some grains of pebble and brick-dust trickle down the wall beh Clo-Clo's head. She looks down, puzzled, and then - very slowly - lifts her head. Enormous HEAD CLOSEUP of Clo-Clo. The mouth goes slack an the eyes widen in the shock of absolute horror. A FLASH of the lipstick dropping from Clo-Clo's limp fing A hoarse cry of terror is broken off by a violent snarl a FLASH of Clo-Clo's body arching back -- almost in the pos of a dance -- away from the assault of something black wh rises from lower left-hand corner of the frame and instan blacks out the entire screen. We FADE ON her still glowing cigarette in the gutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT - Clo-Clo's grave. The coffin, on canvas s supports, is being held over the open grave by four black suited attendants. The priest stands at the head of the grave, dressed in his vestments, and with the open prayer book in his hand. At the grave side are a few mourners, C Clo's mother and her little covey of brothers and sisters all huddled together at the foot of the grave. Between th and the priest stand a small group: Robles, Jerry, Mr. Brunton, Galbraith, Charlie How-Come, the Florist and Belmonte. The priest is just finishing the service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anima ejus, et animae omnium fidelium defunctorum, per misericordiam Dei, requiscant in pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From some distance away we hear the tolling of church bel The attendants slowly begin to lower the coffin into the grave. The florist who had begrudged Clo-Clo one wilted flower comes forward and lays a whole armful of roses on descending coffin. Jerry follows him. He puts Clo-Clo's castanets among the flowers. The coffin sinks slowly from sight. One of the attendants takes a spade. We hear the hollow thump of the first spad as it strikes the casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robles, Charlie, Jerry and Galbraith come out of the ceme together. They are walking slowly, evidently still somewh under the sombre influence of the ceremony they have just witnessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Robles) Have you sent for the state hunters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wired this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: State hunters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professional hunters, who rid the state of cougars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men have paused just outside the cemetery gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulously) You still believe it's the leopard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robles stares at Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you seen the evidence, haven't you heard the testimony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything In Clo-Clo's death, Jerry, to suggest it wasn't the leopard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask Kiki. Ask any woman. Girls don't put on lipstick in the middle of the night on a dark, lonely street unless they're with a man or expecting a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robles and Galbraith look at Jerry. There is some admissi of agreement in their very silence, as they weigh what he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is possible --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the same - - I am going to use the state hunter. Well -- come on, Charlie, I'll give you a lift back into town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robles starts off and Charlie obediently starts after him But Charlie stops and turns back to Jerry and Galbraith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Galbraith) Now I know I didn't hurt nobody when I was drunk - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kindly) Of course, not, Charlie. I never thought you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my leopard - - maybe he hurt the first girl -- but no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, looking satisfied at having had his say, turns a goes off after Robles. Jerry and Galbraith start off in t opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: THE CEMETERY WALL
dialogues.text: TRUCKING SHOT with Robles and Jerry as they walk along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must admit it's possible that it might have been a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just barely possible - - yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry pauses and Galbraith stops and looks at him inquiringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know a lot. You've taken a lot of fancy courses in colleges and that kind of stuff - - what kind of a man would kill like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But all those fancy courses were about the dead, Jerry, not the living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- the dead, then.  In history there must have been men like that -- men with kinks in their brains --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith nods his head. He starts walking slowly forward again and Jerry goes along with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. There have been men who kill for pleasure -- strange pleasure. There was Blue Beard in France -- Jack The Ripper in London. It's not uncommon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there were a man like that, with a kink in his brain around here loose, what would he be like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the eye? Like other men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean that. How would he act? What would he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd act normally when he was with other people. It would be a man who suffered remorse and even pity when it was all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't you tell a man like that when you saw him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He would be a hard man to find, Jerry. Particularly if he were a clever men. He would go about his ordinary business calmly and coolly except when the fit to kill was on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've thought of all this before. You know it isn't the leopard В—В— (insistently) Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith makes no answer. Jerry looks at him and senses finality in this. The two men start walking once more.

dialogues.speaker: KIKI'S DRESSING ROOM
dialogues.text: Jerry, Kiki and Eloise are in the dressing room.        J Kiki are dressed for travelling. Kiki is wearing a suit a her hat and topcoat are on the table. Standing on the flo near the door, are a couple of        suitcases. Both Kik Eloise are holding paper cups in their hands. Jerry is Ju finishing filling Kiki's cup        from a champagne bott

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry crosses to Eloise and fills the cup she holds out. Eloise looks at him with sentimental fondness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear -- I don't know what I'm going to do without you -  honestly, I don't В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Hey В—В— I'm over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not taking her eyes off Jerry) I'll miss you too, honey --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry grins at her. He fills a cup for himself and puts t bottle down on the dressing table. Then he lifts the cup Kiki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -В— here's to luck in Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chicago! Imagine getting out of all this silly scenery and opening in a real city!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little smugly) Not bad, huh? And this place closing for the weekВ—end gives us a couple of extra days to rest up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can use them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they close up every year for this Processionist business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) It's the big religious ceremony around here. You really ought to see the procession -- why don't you wait over В—В— say, who knows, I might be able to scare up some money and go with you then!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) You're sure crazy to get out of here, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what it is to be ambitious -В— but you two are already on your way -- I haven't even started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens, simultaneously with a knock, and a Mexica waiter appears with a large box of flowers in his hands. hands the box of flowers to Jerry, who is        nearest

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These for the Senorita Kiki. And the cab is coming soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily) Okay, Kiki -- here we go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start out. The CAMERA HOLDS ON Eloise as she watches them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki and Jerry are seated side by side in the cab. The bo flowers is between them. It is covered, but the ribbon ha been taken off. Kiki holds a card in her hand. She looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was nice of Mr. Galbraith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a nice guy. Vie ought to keep in touch with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki looks down at the box of flowers. She lifts the box cover a little and then closes it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty. You know -- it's funny but flowers only mean one thing to me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Funerals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the following pause, Kiki looks out the window. Jerry looks over at her, watching her seriously and questioning But as she turns back, he looks away again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry waits, but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry, these flowers aren't really for me В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you want to take them to the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little shame-faced) Yes. Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry leans forward and taps on the glass partition betwe themselves and the driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the arbor-like inclosure, two or three white pigeons a moving about on the sunlit ground. As Kiki and Jerry ente the inclosure, they lift into the air with a flutter of w and fly away. Kiki looks around the little inclosure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she waited here for him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robles says it looks that way. Belmonte had already been there and left. They only missed each other by a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki goes over to the little marble bench and sits down. Jerry stands and looks down at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you suppose she thought about - alone in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's such a sad little place --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki stands looking out at the sunlit trees of the cemete

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you want to stay around here? It'll only make you feel badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I want to feel badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't make sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki turns around and faces him across the belvedere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm tired of pretending that nothing bothers me -- that I don't care about anything but myself - myself and my two-by-four career.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry comes part way across the belvedere to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else do you care about, Kicks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. Us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry comes over and takes her in his arms. He looks into eyes and then kisses her deeply. As he lifts his head aga he holds her even more tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you care about us, Kicks. Sometimes that gets kind of lost in the racket --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up at him) Maybe there ought to be less racket and more us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry smiles at her. Leaving one arm around her shoulders steers her over to the little marble bench. They sit down still with their arms around each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been so busy pretending to be tough hombres --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry nods. With a little sigh, Kiki puts her head down o his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confession. I'm a complete softie. I've been conscience-stricken and worried sick ever since that leopard got away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's being a softie -- there are two of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit quietly -- happy in a moment of complete understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki -- it wasn't the leopard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're positive of that, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki gets to her feet and tugs at Jerry's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to catch a train, darling -- we're going to stay right here and catch a murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) You're sure it's all right? You don't mind staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki smiles up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already know the answer to that. I want this town to be safe and happy again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no detective. I don't even know how to begin. All I know is I want to do something about all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki takes his arm and they start across the inclosure. J stops at the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way -- I'm out of cash --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you take your cut out of the closing check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ruefully) I got into a little crap game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny -- I never knew you to lose that much before --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry looks innocent and helpless..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little embarrassed) As a matter of fact, I'm out of cash myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What! You can't be --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I bought some silver jewelry and stuff from Eloise --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eloise doesn't own enough of anything to make a dent in your pay check, Kicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defiantly) All right, I'm not ashamed of it! I split it two ways В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (before he can continue) Half to the Delgado family and half to Clo-Clo's family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did the same thing yourself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impulsively, Kiki puts her arms around Jerry and hugs him affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old gatekeeper is leaning against the cemetery gate, whittling. Kiki and Jerry the gate. Kiki smiles at him..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just by way of polite observation) Must get lonely here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding toward the graveyard) I have many friends -- and they don't bother me with talk --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jerry) That ought to hold you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie HowВ—Come comes walking towards them, dragging a behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred and fifty dollars you owe met

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very excited) You found the leopard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie comes up to them and drops the sack to the ground

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's left of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? Where did you find it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is wiping his face with Now he gestures with the cloth, a bandana handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: North -- in an arroyo, Shot through the head В—- maybe week ago. No good, skin, everything gone В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What arroyo -В— how did you get to it В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie looks perplexed. He draws a line in the air with forefinger.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHOE SHINING STAND
dialogues.text: A small shoeshine stand with two chairs under an awning. Robles sits in one of them, looking down like a judge at group before him -- Kiki, Jerry and Charlie. The other ch is empty. The little Mexican who runs the stand is workin with furious diligence over Robles' boots. Charlie, the sack lying nearby, is bent over almost doubl tracing an imaginary line on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here is Three Tree Mesa -- and here I go out of the big arroyo --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) That's the place: I remember -В— My feet were so darn sore, I couldn't make it -- and Galbraith went on up to the head of the canyon by himself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a moment В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Kiki and holds out his hand beseechingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- Miss Walker В—В— come up and sit beside me. I cannot stand  В— so you must sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really -- thank you just the same, I В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Chief, don't you understand what this means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) You think Galbraith found the leopard on the day you went out with the posse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure of it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having finished one boot, the Mexican bootblack goes to w on the other. Robles holds up the polished boot and looks it admiringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that beautiful? There is no one in the state like him. He is a genius in his own line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry makes a gesture of impatience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith knows something. He as good as said so В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not interested in what somebody else thinks. You being me facts and I'll act on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry kicks at the sack with his foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a fact, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And I am taking it to headquarters for examination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bootblack puts the final buff on the second boot. Rob steps down. He pats the bootblack on the shoulder and han him a coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't go to Galbraith with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Offend a reputable citizen and involve the department in a slander suit? No. I'm in office to protect the taxpayers money В— not throw it way. Come on, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie picks up the sack and trails away after Robles.  Jerry stares after them. The his arm. Jerry looks at him. bootblack makes a gesture of buffing and points down to Jerry's shoes.  Jerry shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, thanks. (to Kiki) Now we've got to do it ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (encouragingly) We will В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry takes her arm and they start walking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a small, simply furnished bedroom with a day-bed. Raul Belmonte is sprawled on this couch. His hair is rump he needs a shave and his shirt is badly wrinkled. His fac and eyes show the effects of constant drinking. A bottle glass stand on the floor beside the head of the couch. Je is looking over at a photograph which stands on a small t in the window В—- a photograph of Consuelo Contreras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lovely face, a tender smile, soft beautiful hair -В— that's what you see in the photograph, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raul props himself on one elbow and looks across at the photograph himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a hard voice) A smear of blood, clawed rags in a huddle on the ground --that's what I see. A horrid, terrible thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) I know. I was there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raul swings himself into a sitting position on the edge o the couch. He puts his head into his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you aren't here when she calls out at night. Wake up and hear her  - screaming В—- "Raul, Raul, get me out"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry goes over to him and puts his hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, boy. I want to talk to you. Maybe there's something I can do В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raul reaches down and gets the bottle and the glass. He starts automatically to pour a drink for himself В—В— the stops and holds out the bottle and glass to Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a drink. That's the best thing to wipe out nightmares В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry takes the bottle-and glass and carries them over to table. He puts them down and then comes back to Raul, who sat watching him stupidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You've got to kick at something, fight with something, to work the nightmares out of your system. In Consuelo's case, there's been nothing to fight against -В— just fate and a dumb brute animal. (pauses to watch Raul) I've got something to tell you that will change all that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raul looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't an animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raul frowns and moves uneasily, trying to understand thro his alcoholic haze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) A man -В— killed Consuelo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry nods his head. Raul slowly gets to his feet and sta eye to eye with Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. But I want your help to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raul goes over to the table and picks up the bottle. He p some liquor into the glass and takes it off quickly, as i were medicine. Then he turns back to Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: INTERSECTION OF THE ALLEY AND THE STREET
dialogues.text: The commemorative procession is forming here. Some of the participants are hooded, wearing black hoods very much li these worn by the Ku Klux Klanners. In the doorways and windows, the townspeople are watching. Galbraith passes through the crowd. He has a small paper package in his hand, his pipe in his mouth and is walking along, obviously on his way to somewhere. Eloise, who is standing watching the Processionists, blocks his way for moment. He tries to pass around her. She sees him and smi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Galbraith! I'm so glad you're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little puzzled and trying to pass on) Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping him) You know all about these things - - and I've lived here all my life В—- and I still don't know what the Procession means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's to remind people of the great tragedy that took place here so that they won't ever forget that a peaceful village of Indians was wiped out by the Conquistadores, back in the 17th Century... A band of monks buried the dead and prayed for them and did penance for their deaths В—В— that's what this procession is supposed to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gushing) Oh, that's so interesting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now that you've had your history lesson, I think I'll get on to the museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods and starts off. Eloise turns back to watch the Processionists.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CEMETERY WALL
dialogues.text: Galbraith is walking along the quiet, empty street outsid the cemetery wall. There is a very faint cry from inside the cemetery. Galbraith slows his stride perceptibly, but does not stop
