dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., very faint) Help! Get me out! Help! Help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith stops and looks up at the cemetery wall,  CLOSEUP of Galbraith shows fear and puzzlement in his eye Still looking toward the wall, Galbraith walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith is walking along the brick wall, approaching th corner. Just before he gets to the corner, a lighted cigarette spins out and falls to the pavement in front of him.        Galbraith stops as if he had come up against stands there, forcing courage to go on. He takes the few steps to the corner and faces the direction from which th cigarette was thrown. There is on one in sight anywhere. Very slowly, Galbraith reaches down and picks up the cigarette. The unlighted end is dark with lipstick. With almost imperceptible shudder, Galbraith lets the cigarett fall. Walking rigidly, he continues on his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The large room is in shadowy darkness. The heavy front do swings open. Suddenly the place is brilliantly lighted fr the overhead fixtures. Galbraith takes his hand from the light-switch just inside the door. He pushes the clear cl and leans up against it exhaustedly. He is breathing heav and his eyes are dull and heavy-lidded with the reaction violent fear. He sighs deeply and then walks slowly and wearily across display room to the office alcove. He sits down at his worktable and starts work on a small model of Indian ruin done in colored clays. Suddenly, far away but clear in the silence, he hears the sound of castanets В—В— just three widely spaced clicks. hands becomes motionless above the model В—-but he does n look up. The same sound comes again, repeated twice, the clicks a little more rapid. Galbraith gets to his feet and stands staring into the em brilliantly lighted museum room. The castanets sound again and this time they go into a st rhythm, still faint and faraway; a purr of sound. But the sound increases in volume and intensity every second. Galbraith listens, his eyes mirroring his growing terror, hands pressing down onto the worktable. The castanets come up to a brainВ—splitting reverberation sound. The tendons in Galbraith's neck stand out В—В— his forehead is wet with sweat. As the tenseness of his body and the madness in his eyes signal that his control is about to break В—В— the castan furor abruptly ceases. For another few seconds, Galbraith stands there  Then he lifts his hands from the table and draws in a deep shudde breath. He takes a handkerchief from his pocket and slowl wipes his face and his bands. Re steps out of the alcove and presses a lightВ—switch on wall nearby. The overhead lights in the display room go o The alcove is new like a little lighted stage at the end dark auditorium. Galbraith steps back into it, takes a bo from the worktable and settles down in an armchair at one of the table. He begins to read. The sound of the front door opening breaks suddenly into stillness. It brings Galbraith to his feet in an instant. book falls to the floor. Across the shadowy display room, a figure moves to the accompaniment of a woman's brisk footsteps. There is no terror in Galbraith's face this time -- but h waits tensely to-identify his visitor. Kiki steps into the lighted alcove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've disturbed        you. I'm sorry -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Walker -- I didn't expect anyone В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki steps closer to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetically) I came up on the spur of the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith leans down and picks up the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to        see the procession В—В— and I remembered your kind invitations        --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles a little uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Only I'm afraid you'll be cheated. There isn't much of a view of the procession here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) I thought they came right past here В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do, but -- there are no lights out there В—- they'll just be shadows -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki moves across the alcove to a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not so terribly dark out. If we turn off these lights, we can see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A panic-stricken look leaps into Galbraith's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no trace of fear in his voice) No use turning the lights out until they get here..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki stands looking out at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they're coming now, listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very faintly, in the far distance, can be heard the chant of the procession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith listens as if he wore listening to Fate itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn off the lights --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith stares across at her. With great effort, he spe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thickly) Wait В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No В—- really, I can see them -- they're coming now -В— turn off the lights В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if hypnotized, Galbraith walks out of the alcove and t the light-switch on the nearby wall. His fingers move up towards the second switch.. He still stares toward Kiki. has the set, bloodless look of a man-lost in some fearful resolve. CLOSE SHOT of Kiki. For the first time, we see that she i terrified. She is looking at the window where Galbraith i faintly mirrored. CLOSE SHOT of Galbraith's hand on the light-switch. The fingers curve claw-like as he pushes down the switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the window, the reflection is blotted out. Outside we can see the processionists marching. The pin points of their candles are making bright spots against t dark background of their robes and the night sky. The loa chants and the rest answer him monotonously, over and ove again. Kiki stands at the window. Behind her Galbraith crosses f the light switch, walking normally, his footsteps followi one another with great regularity. Kiki stands perfectly still, keeping her eyes to the wind Only her left hand slowly rising to press against her hea betrays her anxiety. As the hand rises we pick up the bea her heart. (Trick effect.) Galbraith comes closer and closer until finally he stands behind her. The beating of her heart subsides. There is perfect silence. Even the processionists cease their chan for a moment. Kiki and Galbraith stand this, way for an instant,, then suddenly Galbraith moves violently toward She screams. The side door bursts open and Jerry and Belm come pellВ—mell into the room. It has all happened with such suddenness that for a momen Galbraith stands stock still. The two grapple with him. T physical contact rouses him. He shakes himself loose and dodges around the desk. They chase after him through the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith runs in, followed closely by Jerry and Belmonte dodges among the showcases. He tries the great door. It h been locked. He turns and starts running back toward the alcove. They stop him. He dodges them and goes on. Jerry starts after him again. Belmonte reaches under his coat a pulls out a revolver. The movement has caught Jerry's eye he turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raoul -- don't. Put that gun away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry runs on, without seeing whether or not Raoul has ob his order. With the gun still in his hand, Raoul follows after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galbraith runs in past Kiki, who has left the window and standing in front of the desk. Just as he passes her, Jerry reaches him, grabs his arm and whips him around. Th two men struggle. Belmonte comes up. To avoid the struggl men, Kiki steps backward and knocks against the showcase containing the butterflies. It falls with a great crash a the sound of breaking glass, Kiki falls with it. Jerry glances over and sees Kiki on the floor. He lets go Galbraith who dodges out of the side door, Belmonte after him. Jerry kneels down beside Kiki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. I'm not hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scrambles up from his knees and runs after Belmonte. The processionists slowly climb the hill toward the cross The leader is still calling out and the others answer him the long established rigmarole of their ceremonies. Galbr with a hurried look over his, shoulder runs into the scen and slips in with the marching men. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Galbraith as he makes him way to the center of the marching column. Jerry and Belmonte stand panting beside the marching colu of processionists. He looks right and loft. There is no s of Galbraith. He, too, falls in the rank near the end of procession. He begins to slowly make his way to the head the column, peering under the hats and into the dark face the men. His gun is still in his hand. ANOTHER ANGLE of the marching column. We see Galbraith in very center and behind him Jerry and Belmonte come up and look into his face. They seize his arms. Galbraith strugg to get away from them. There is a disturbance in the rank the processionists. Quickly, six of the enormous, tall, hooded figures gather menacingly around the center of the disturbance. No word is spoken. There is only the converg of these six great figures about the two struggling men. three men subside. Galbraith ceases to struggle. The six hooded men leave them, drawing back to the flanks of the procession. CLOSER SHOT of Jerry and Galbraith. The two men are close together, but march on in step with the processionists, a as they walk, they talk sotto voce. Despite the urgency o what one demands from the other and the other denies, the silent authority of the hooded figures mutes their voices

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was you, Galbraith!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not! I tell you. No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shot the leopard. We know that. You killed Consuelo. You killed Clo Clo. Then tonight --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do anything. She screamed. Something frightened her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo screamed too -- and Clo Clo. Why did you do it? Why? Quick. Tell me why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brokenly, very near hysteria) It's better you don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do yo&i accuse me? You don't know what you're doing -- you don't understand -- nobody understands --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry studies Galbraith. A new note has crept into the ma voice -- an odd note of irrationality and selfВ—pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miserably) In the whole world there isn't a single human being who knows what it is to be tormented this way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The procession has reached the crest of the hill. As the of the column begins to make its way around the cross the whole file slows from a march to a shuffling half step. J and Belmonte seize the opportunity to edge Galbraith out the column toward a Joshua tree. They stand in its deep shadow while the procession goes on and off. CLOSE SHOT of Jerry and Galbraith, with Belmonte close to Galbraith in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (prompting Galbraith) Tormented -- ? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't rest В—- I couldn't sleep. All I could see was Teresa Delgado's body -- broken --mangled. I saw it day and night.  It was waiting everywhere I turned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you found the leopard --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to kill, but I had to. I heard her in the cemetery - talking to the man in the auto --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belmonte stirs in the shadow of the Joshua tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he went away -- I thought maybe I was going to help her get over the wall -- I can't remember. В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of Belmonte. His face is motionless В—- his ey are burning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with mounting hysteria) I looked down -- in the darkness I saw her white face turned up to me -- the eyes dark and wide with fear -- the fear -- that was it -- the little frail body -- the soft skin В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, Galbraith's two hands lift, the fingers curved slightly inwards. He looks at them as if he, too, were terrified by their deadly potentiality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then -- (smiles, strangely and appallingly) В—В—        she screamed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind him, Belmonte comes up close. Agony passes over Belmonte's face and contorts it... His hand squeezes down the gun. A shot roars out. Galbraith falls, silently crumpling down at the base of the Joshua tree. Belmonte throws the gun away and stands looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Consuelo,

dialogues.speaker: EXT UNDERTAKER'S PARLOUR
dialogues.text: T. C.  Johnson' s undertaking parlour is lighted and the light falls out of the window in. a great broad path onto dark sidewalk. Jerry and Kiki come out of the        buil pause and stand in the broad glow of light from the windo For a moment they are silent. Behind them, in the shop, w see Raoul Hobbs and two policemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stood here once before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know -- Teresa -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hated you that day В—- you and your flip talk -В— with that little girl lying dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. What do you think I felt when you said, "don't be soft?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry, I want you to be soft. You are soft -- inside -В— where it matters. I wanted it that day too, but didn't dare tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ought to dare to tell each other everything, Kiki -- you and I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Re looks up and down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a strange town, Kiki. A funny town. Mexican, American and Indian, all mixed up in itself, with two languages. The sign posts written in Spanish and English. A strange town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE showing the street. Four hooded processioni go by in single file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lovely town В—- it was until we came and let the leopard loose and all this happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiki, Galbraith said something to me once, -- something you ought to know. We were talking and he said that people were like that ball on the fountain at the hotel --they got pushed around by things bigger than themselves. That's the way it was with us -- and we were too small to see it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his arm about her and they begin to walk up the street.
